summary: At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a tennis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that one of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, none of which were recovered. Four further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.
200-150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 48 denarii are known today: Nero – Hadrian (AD 125-128).
Hoard of 282 coins: 252 denarii, 1 quinarius, 29 bronzes: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

The hoard comprised numerous copper-alloy vessels, a mirror, a folding seat, Samian ware cups and plates and six glass bottles, one of which contained 40 very worn sestertii and dupondii of Nerva, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
The hoard was hidden inside the camp: 25 aurei, 610 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans, as well as gold and silver jewelry in a bronze cauldron: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166).
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Regensburg, Germany

summary: 10 denarii: Trajan – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162).
disposition: NPÚ-ÚOP Pardubice, Náchod Castle collection, Czech Republic (inv.nos. 2.920, 3.016-3.023).

summary: The hoard comprised 5 sestertii, dupondii or asses from Tiberius to Commodus and was found in association with a key handle, an incense burner, two statues (one being of Mercury) and a statue base. The remains of a Roman building, the function of which was undetermined, was found close by.
130 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 360.44 g. Together with the coins were found two bronze rings.
3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised six bronze coins dated between AD 70-81 and AD 117/118. It was deposited inside the hollow part of a door frame in the tepidarium of a Roman bathhouse. Votive role?
The hoard comprised 112 sestertii: Trajan-Septimius Severus (98-196 AD).

The deposit was found under a second century occupation layer in the central part of the Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 4 sestertii from Trajan to Antoninus Pius and two asses of Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 153 to 154.
112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
The hoard comprised 10 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. TAF interprets the hoard as being a purse drop.
The hoard comprised a mixed hoard of gold, silver, and bronze deposited in relation to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Unknown initial number of coins. 22 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 139)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest

summary: Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

Hoard of 36 coins (31 bronze and 6 silver) "from 76 BC to AD 180 or 270" found during Pitt Rivers' excavations at the settlement site of Woodcutts, Sixpenny Handley. Said to have been found with the remains of a bronze-mounted casket near a hearth, possibly within a house."... the discovery here, within an oblong area of ' depression ' and near a hearth, of the remains of a bronze-mounted ornamental casket, with glass, a silver spoon, a penannular brooch, etc., and 31 bronze and 6 silver coins, from Claudius I to Claudius II (268-70)". (Hawkes, C.F.C. 1947, 'Britons, Romans, and Saxons Round Salisbury and in Cranborne Chase: reviewing the excavations of General Pitt-Rivers, 1881-1898' Archaeological Journal 104, p.46).

Around 200 denarii. The person who ppresented 46 denarii mentioned that in total may have found around 200 pieces. Only 28 coins could be described. One denarius of Antoninus Pius was found in 2010: Vitellius - Clodius Albinus (AD 194-197).
2 denarii of Trajan and Hadrian.

A hoard of four denarii (2 Domitian and 2 Trajan) was found during field-walking in the South Annexe of the fort at Newstead. The coins were recovered in a little roll, with possible traces of a copper/bronze container.
6 denarii, probably, part of a larger hoard: Antoninus Pius 3, Faustina I (Diva) 1, Antoninus Pius (Divus) 2
3,561 coins of Lucius Verus.
53 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Circumstances of discovery are unknown.
(c. 3000-3500) 474 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
37 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927 and 1928, now, in a private collection: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 101.03 g.
disposition: Private collection Axel O. Larsson, Stockholm

summary: A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.
8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
Hoard of 1000 denarii of the Antonines and 6 aurei of Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by two treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by one of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
9 coins: 1 aureus, 3 denarii, 1 sestertius, 4 asses: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Split, Croatia; partly dispersed

summary: Unknown number of denarii. There is information on four coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).
76 gold coins found in the nineties: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD

The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.
A hoard of denarii found at Brixworth, in 1892. It is complete except for one denarius of Antoninus Pius of uncertain reverse. Coins range from Vespasian to Crispina.

The hoard comprised a double deposit within a single room of a building. In one corner of the room, there were four coins, including one of Marcus Aurelius, 1 of Lucilla and 2 of Commodus. In the opposite corner, there was an identical deposit.
270 coins. Only 10 sestertii are known: Trajan, - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection vicar Verstraete, Kortrijk, Belgium (c. 155 coins), in 1846; collection .C. Lefèvre,Brugge, Belgium (10 coins), in 1846

summary: A hoard of unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: 64 denarii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Some 650 provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150). 'Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina monetaria".
55 billon drachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-155) found at floor level in a room during excavations of a house.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 27 coins are known at the moment: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 161-175).
Unknown number of coins. 46 coins of Nerva and 31 of Hadrian were in possession of the antiquarian Fornier.
(90) 27 denarii: 7 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel.

A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in one lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.

18 denarii of which two imitations (one hybrid) found as a lump: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). The imitation denarii were struck with the same dies as other two denarii found in Ukraine (Dymowski 2017)
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five denarii are known: Tiberius - Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.

Arm purse containing 63 coins (3 aurei and 60 denarii), ranging from the late Republic to Hadrian, found while quarrying stones. Each of the gold coins was wrapped up in a separate piece of greenish leather or vellum, which was still quite tough and strong.
disposition: Clayton Memorial Museum, Chesters (purse). The coins are said to have been given to the Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, but have not been located there

summary: Two denarii found on a field: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 185).

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
The hoard of 175 gold and silver Iron Age coins, and 23 Roman denarii, ranging from from c. 50 BC to the latter half of the second century AD, uncovered on a field at Waltham St. Lawrence.
79 coins: 6 denarii, 45 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 12 asses found with shreds from the ceramic vessel: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
Hoard of 171 denarii, only 139 were recorded: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum Complex Iași, Romania (121 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (50 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 26 denarii are known at the moment: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
16 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: 41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: Hoard of 450 denarii found with a ceramic vessel covered by another pot: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Weight: 983 g. According to Kropotkin, the hoard ends with the coin of Clodius Albinus as all the coins of Septimius Severus are issues of AD 193-194.
disposition: Local History Museum, Uman, Ukraine (inv. nos. 1675/2760 et 2355/3440)

summary: 14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver weight: 22.67 g (8 coins).
Grup of two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I); silver weight: 5.32 g.
918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
4 denarii: Vitellius, Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-160).
The hoard comprised around 500 tetradrachms and at least 2000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
A hoard of 12 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) was found during the archaeological excavation of a building thought to be a granary and comprised of thirteen Denarii coins.
A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
Two denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).
31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian
58 denarii to Antoninus Pius (plus a probably unrelated IA stater) (not connected with the siliqua hoard from same parish)
The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
(25) 15 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 426

summary: The hoard of 79 denarii (one Republican denarius; imperial coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius) and one Lycian drachm was found in 1882 during plowing of a court at Middels-Osterloog. The coins lay in a container.
Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
81 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while building a new house: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
30 denarii: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). Found near the Roman villa.
33 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: County Museum of Bistrița-Năsăud, Bistrița, Romania; Inv.no. MB 20918-20950

summary: Seven aurei: Vespasian - Hadrian. No further information.
The hoard comprised 214 Alexandrian tetradrachms from Claudius I to Hadrian. They were found under a floor surface during the excavation of a Late Roman house.
76 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179).
(21) 19 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Trajan - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
1000 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - in an ancient building. The latest coins belong to Antoninus Pius.
9 coins: 5 denarii, 4 sestertii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: 31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found two silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.
102 sestertii, 5 dupondii and 1 as ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180). Hoard was originally larger.
In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.

A Roman arm purse was found on a field, southwest of Hahn (today in the district of Pfungstadt), in the vicinity of the Hofgut Grabenbruch. The purse contained 8 Roman denarii, ranging from Galba to Trajan.
22 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
Around 70-80 denarii, 53 were recovered: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.

177 denarii with portraits of emperors from Vespasian to Trajan and two denarii of Mark Antony's 'legionary' series. The denarii were found with a ceramic vessel. The metal analyses, fresh minting loo-alike state of preservation for the large majority of the coins as well as the overweight for most of the coins reveal a 'hoard' of ancient counterfeited coins. The dating of coin type is based on the genuine prototype, otherwise, it looks that they were all minted in/after AD 116.
disposition: Museum of National Union, alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 2nd century. Hoard of 8 coins recovered with a frag. of a bronze vessel, possibly its original container. The coins all exclusively 2nd C terminating with issue of Crispina (AD 177-183), though hoard may have been deposited in 3rd C AD.Rudling, D. 1982. The Romano-British farm on Bullock Down. In P. Drewett (ed.) The Archaeology of Bullock Down, Eastbourne, East Sussex.
Three denarii (Nerva - Faustina II), found with others on a field in Halsmühlen.
The hoard comprised 96 bronze coins from the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: Five bronze coins found one next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.
Unknown originally number of coins. 59 bronze coins are known: 51 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).

West Parade site Area III, Roman interval tower. In late Roman period, interval tower became derelict, & much of upper part prob. demolished/ robbed. Lower part of tower infilled with demolition debris, incl. ceramic tile frags. & mortar, animal bone waste from food consumption, & bird & animal skeletons, incl. ravens & dogs, frogs & toads, & remains of owl pellets. 3 silver denarii in fine condition also found amongst demolition debris, of Trajan, Hadrian & Faustina, minted in early to mid 2nd C. before tower even built; & it is likely that they were hidden & subsequently lost, poss. as part of a larger hoard, whilst tower was still in use.Gilmour, B. 1999. Excavations. In C. Colyer, B.J.J. Gilmour & B. Jones The Defences of the Lower City. Excavations at The Park and West Parade 1970-2 and a Discussion of Other Sites Excavated up to 1994. The Archaeology of Lincoln VIII-2. CBA Res. Report 114, pp. 191.
Five denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of the Buchow-Karpzow estate, probably only part of a larger find.
50 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 137.84 g.
30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: Galba to Severus. The number of coins in the hoard is estimated and falls somewhere between 1200 and 1500 denarii and 1 drachm of Amisus for Hadrian. Found with a ceramic vessel and few silver ingots.
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum (64 denarii; 1 drachm of Amisus)

summary: 52 aurei ranging from Nero (AD 63/66) to Marcus Aurelius (AD 164), found at the Stephansgasse, in the foundations of a stone building. This hoard could be connected with the Marcomannic wars.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
Around 142 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (143 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a grave in the Gallo-Roman cemetery. A red ceramic urn was discovered, alongside a small bronze box containing a gold finger ring with glass setting and three aurei of Nero, Domitian and Antoninus Pius. It is not altogether clear whether the coins were found in the box or the urn.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 25 coins were seen: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoards with Strunga I and III.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: A hoard of 304 silver coins (303 denarii and 1 drachm), ranging from Nero to Commodus, found in summer 2019 (with 6 additional coins found in 2020) on the Adlerberg, near Pratteln.
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).
307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: 1,776 denarii (5.5 kg): Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Most likely were kept in a wooden box, as eight silver rivets "have been discovered at the site".
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.
The hoard comprised 13 silver coins dated between AD 62/3 and AD 123.
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: 84 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel; Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); weight: 281 g.
disposition: Muzeului de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra-Neamț, Romania

summary: Six denarii found together on a floor of a Roman edifice from the Dacian kingdom capital of Sarmizegetusa Regia Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102).
disposition: Muzeul Civilizației Dacice și Romane, Deva, Romania

summary: Hoard of 120 coins: 2 aurei, 118 denarii: Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museo de San Isidro, Los Orígenes de Madrid

summary: The hoard comprised a few tetradrachms and approximately 50 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

A small hoard of 10 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2021 somewhere in Poltava region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity, March 18, 2021. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
1,268 coins: 7 aurei, 1,261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total weight: 4,023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: 199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not one hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.

322 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 181-182). The hoard also includes silver and gold jewelry. Gold: 1 bracelet, 1 ring. Silver: 1 patera, 1 chain, 2 brooches, 1 necklace, 1 bracelet, 2 cups. All items were placed in a silver casket.
The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Antonine coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.
From 465 only 60 denari are known: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Found in a ceramic vessel.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
The hoard comprised 31 tetradrachms, 17 denarii, and 7 bronze coins from the Bar Kohba Revolt (AD 132-136) and one denarius of Trajan.

Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and four rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.

Originally 5 denarii, 2 preserved: Hadrian, Hadrian (Sabina), Antoninus Pius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla); silver weight: 4.61 g. (2 coins). Not certain that they were found together!

Råmosen, the numerically largest denarii hoard in Denmark, was found in 1782. The hoard consists of 428 denarii. There are two lists of coins for the hoard; one lists the end coin as a Marcus Aurelius, but there are contemporary letters mentioning coins with a portrait of Crispina.
38 bronze coins: 2 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 28 asse, 4 dupondii or asses: Titus - Commodus (AD 192).
Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: A hoard of 9 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB and VC) and one sestertius of Commodus. The coins were excavated in 1936 in front of the north end of the Stoa of Attalos (grid P 7). When found, several of the coins were stuck together, suggesting that all ten were originally put away in a purse.
The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.
Grup of three denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.
92 silver coins, 90 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175); weight: 292.04 g.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra Neamț, Romania (inv.nos. 28530-

summary: 100 coins of which one bronze coin of Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
disposition: Private collection and museum Eindhoven, Netherlands

summary: A roll of eight corroded and partly worn AE coins (Trajan to Lucius Verus), found within the group of furnaces north of the west gate (inside the Roman fort), in front of the furnace 5

The hoard comprised 116 silver coins: 111 denarii, 1 denarius serratus, 2 quinarii, 2 drachms: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158). Found in a ceramic vessel with a terra sigillata bowl serving as a lid.
Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.
The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including two coins of Juba II, one of Nero, one of Galba, nineteen of Vespasian, seven of Titus, twenty-three of Domitian, three of Nerva, forty-eight of Trajan and ten of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified two of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes ten extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: one Republican denarius, one denarius of Vespasian, two denarii of Domitian, five denarii of Trajan and one Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the nine latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
189 denarii: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași (134 coins), History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (21 coins), History Museum, Onești (13 coins); Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra-Neamț (22 coins)

summary: Unknown number of denarii found in two small ceramic vessels placed 100 m from each other. 38 pieces are known from one of the vessels: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 44-81

summary: Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.

After the war in a building excavation pit, 30 Roman denarii (Galba to Lucilla) were found in an amber-glazed jar from the sixteenth century, wrapped individually in a linen cloth. It is likely that a Roman hoard was unearthed in the Renaissance, and has now been found for the second time.

A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.
60 denarii: Galba/Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
2500-3000 denarii. 250 pieces were bought by the National Museum in Sofia: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Six (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, three were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "two years ago" two aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).
Two sestertii found together and recorded as a hoard in the HER. The coins could not be closely identified and were returned to the finder as they did not meet the criteria for Treasure.
The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.
The hoard comprised 100 Roman coins, including one of Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only for 7 cois is given Information on the issuers: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 172-192).
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
85 denarii: Nerva - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: Hoard of circa 60 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 18 denarii were documented.
10 denarii found on a field: Trajan - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 26.87 g.
237 provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144). Two sacks found in a house during excavations.
272 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 119-122).
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.
368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
The coins were found together, in a burnt layer 25 cm deep under Plattenstraße at Ritona.
Hoard of 49 coins and jewelry was found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Jewelry: bronze loop, bronze buckle, silver buckle, 7 silver rings, 39 pearls of amber, coral, glass.
disposition: Local history museum Cherkasy, Ukraine (inv.no. 190092 - vanished in 1941-1945)

summary: A hoard of about 500 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by a treasure hunter somewhere near the Dniester, on the borderland of the Ternopil and Ivano-Frankivsk region. The hoard was found in a pot (a few fragments are preserved). Several coins were glued to the fragments of the vessel. The coins are quite well preserved (minimal wear). Deposit was not published on Violity, and was immediately sold to one of the collectors. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
3 denarii: Titus, Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 148-149); silver weight: 7.90 g.
157 coins found in a ceramic vessel: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
The hoard comprised 25 coins (23 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 Provincial bronze of Trajan of the Koinon of Cyprus), ranging from Titus to Antoninus Pius.
102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).
Six denarii (Domitian - Hadrian), found in the estuary of the River Weser in 1842.

A small hoard of 21 Roman imperial denarii (from Domitian to Commodus) and three bronze artefacts was found by a treasure hunter in March 2016 somewhere in Central Ukraine, probably in Cherkassy region. On March 10, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity was published information about the hoard and a photo of the coins and items from it (the finder identified the deposit as a “purse of denarii”). There is no information about the conditions of the find. The coins have heavy wear, one of the coins has strong oxide traces. The bronze items are rectangular in shape and are most likely belt plate: two measure 4.5x0.7cm and one (with six rivets) measures 4.3x1.3cm. In March 2016 the hoard was sold at the Violity auction, and the further fate of the coins is unknown.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins and some bronzes, including one of Faustina I.
Around 40 silver coins. Only 4 denarii of Antoninus Pius are known.
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .

The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
"1 litra" of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 2 denarii are known: Domitian, Trajan.
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warszaw (2 coins), Poland

summary: 10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.

Over 486 silver and bronze coins found in four ceramic vessels. Found 3 m from KRISTENDORF 1. Vessel a: 38 denarii: Mark Antony 2, Nero 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 11, Titus 1, Domitian 4, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 5, Faustina I 4, Marcus Aurelius 1, Faustina II 2, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1. Vessel b: 151 sestertii: Galba 1, Vespasian 1, Titus 2, Domitian 2, Trajan 12, Hadrian 23, Antoninus Pius 28, Faustina I 11, Marcus Aurelius 24, Faustina II 13, Lucius Verus 5, Lucilla 7, Commodus 15, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Damna 1, Caracalla 1. Vessel c: 237 bronze coins: Vespasian 1, Titus 1, Domitian 3, Trajan 13, Hadrian 41, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 32, Faustina II 11, Marcus Aurelius 56, Faustina II 34, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 8, Commodus 24, Crispina 1, uncertain 4. Vessel d: 60 sestertii: Titus 1, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 5, Sabina 1, Antoninus Pius 13, Faustina I 2, Marcus Aurelius 14, Faustina II 11, Lucilla 2, Commodus 4, Crispina 1, uncertain 2.
A hoard of 20+ Roman silver coins (i.e. certainly denarii), found while digging out peat on the Dörpstedter Moor.
Initially 368 denarii, nowadays, 367: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 1009.47 g.
disposition: The National Historical Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 10155/1-167, 169-368); Stockholm Numismatic Institute, Stockholm (inv.no. 179)

summary: Penhallurick 2009, 269: "The museum on St Mary's has three sestertii found in a midden layer on the southern shoreline of Tean in 1956. Accompanying pottery indicated an occupation from the first to the fourth centuries and included sherds of samian ware and a bronze brooch (Thomas 1985, p.183)". He notes that the second sestertius of Marcus Aurelius listed here may have been turned into a brooch (bronze adhered to the bottom of the reverse), though this has not been verified.
Unknown originally number of coins. 20 denarii are kept in the Town museum of Târgoviște: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149).
About 5000 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
NA
(c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).
408 denari found by metal detecting: Nero - Hadrian. No further detail.
The hoard apparently comprised 68 denarii, although the catalogue gives a total of 59 coins.
12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).
A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which one coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of two Roman querns.
2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the one Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).

Discovered in 2007 in a field, near a village, between the village and the Lyasnaya river; the coins were scattered over an area of 500x100 m and had two large concentrations (two hoards?). Included at least 500 denarii, of which only 20 are available for study (Vespasian-Clodius Albinus). Information about the hoard in 2009 came to the archaeologist V. Belyavets, and in the spring of 2010 V. Sidarovich examined the place of the find. In the same field, other items were found: fragments of silver brooches, a gold brooch, a spearhead, a gold ring (?). Their relation with the hoard is doubtful (items from the settlement?)
Originally, 222 coins. 133 denarii are documented: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Iron Gates Museum, Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (122 coins); inv.no. 562-683; private collection, Bucharest, Romania. (11 coins)

summary: A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.
It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and one of the Faustinas.
36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
(c. 50) 25 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 3 asses: House of Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169)

46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any one took the trouble to pick them up."
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
The hoard comprised more than 400 worn coins including issues of Nero, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Crispina.
(700) 612 silver coins: 610 denarii, 2 drachmas: Nero-Commodus (AD 184-185).

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: 154 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: According to W. Łonak, the coins were kept by the Provincial Heritage Department for Cultural-Historical Soil Alterations in Racibórz.

summary: The hoard comprised more than a hundred copper alloy coins of Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Commodus.
Hoard of 17 aurei. Only two are known: Pertinax, Septimius Severus.

The hoard discovered no later than 1900; the total number of coins is unknown. A city dweller with the surname Shapiro bought 44 coins (Vespasian-Commodus; total weight 127.43 g), of which only eight were identified in the Imperial Archaeological Commission (by E. Pridik) and then were returned to the owner.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,600 aureii, from Julius Caesar to Commodus. Most of the hoard was immediately dispersed and sold.
The hoard comprised at least 54 silver coins dated between the Roman Republic and Hadrian (AD 117-138).

In 1844, numerous skeletons were found, buried one on top of the other. One wearing an iron mail shirt, also possessed 'un coeur en bronze doré', 17 denarii and 4 bronze coins. Like TAF V. 33, the assemblage has been interpreted as representing the savings of a soldier killed in the battle between Septimius Severus and Clodius Albinus in AD 197.
Group of 3 Roman coins: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II) dupondius (AD 161-180).
A hoard of 61 Roman coins to Hadrian and 616 Iron Age bronze coins found some years ago in Southants. It was contained in an earthenware pot which was broken in the course of the discovery.
disposition: British Museum (part); Hunter Coin Cabinet, Glasgow (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: At least 4 denarii found on a field: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I).
(over 100) 3 sestertii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 169).
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
15 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 161-180). Only 7 denarii are kept in the coin room of the National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia, 7 coins; dispersed

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Vespasian 1, Nerva 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I 1, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2429

summary: 54 Republican and imperial denarii issued by M. Fonteius, L. Marcius Censorinus, C. Naevius Balbus, M. Cordius, L. Plautius, A. PLautius, P. Clodius Turrinus, L. Thorius Balbus, Sextus Pompeius, Julius Caesar, Mark Antony's legionary denarii (III, VI, VIIII, XII, XIX, XII) des denarii of Sex. Pompey (with reverses of Amphinomos and Anapias), Julius Caesar and emperors to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised 60 silver coins from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian, deposited during the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-136). These coins were: 42 denarii (Vespasian to Hadrian), 10 tetradrachms and 1 tridrachm from Antioch (Nero to Trajan), 6 tridrachms and 1 drachm of Trajan from Arabia.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including one plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
70 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Hadrian.
41 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) (AD 161)
Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.
The hoard comprised 20 denarii from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192) and was found inside an ostrich egg.
Group of 3 coins: Domitian denarius, Trajan denarius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
A hoard of 3-400 aurei. 42 coins were recovered. They are all issues of Lucius Verus, 3 types (Coh. 157, 247, 248).
disposition: Royal Coin Room, Amsterdam, Netherlands (3 coins since 1894); 1 coin in Berlin

summary: A hoard of four aurei: Nero, Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva).
disposition: Madras Museum, Chennai except for Trajan coins

summary: 21 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised 4 coins including one earlier coin of Thasos (2nd c. BC) and two Roman Provincial coins: Philippoi (1 imperial period), Topeiros (1 Antoninus Pius) and a further 1 unidentified coin, found in grave T11 in Lithochori.
52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.
Initially, there were 1,500 aurei. 144 aurei studied: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162). Together were found one gold and two silver ingots.
65 Roman silver coins found a small urn or earthern vessel, while removing the root of a tree near the house of Mr. Burke, at Beaconsfield. The coins ranged from Vespasian to Faustina.
Two aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.
15 of the sestertii from a larger hoard were identified by S. Bottin. The hoard was originally located in Bellaing in error.
Some coins, unknown denomination, of Nerva, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius
Hoard of 177 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 197). Together were found two silver rings and one of gold.
The hoard was found on the West of "Blanche-Fontaine" district. A worker discovered an amphora with 1000 aurei, only 164 are now recorded from Augustus to Hadrian.
16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
10 coins found compacted together during excavations in Tofts Field in 1974. Recovered from surface of first re-metalling of Dere Street, to the east of the later fort, in Tofts Field.

A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.

Three denarii (1 of Trajan and 2 of Septimius Severus that share the same obverse die) from the same context (C/26/34), that may represent a small hoard, found at Kifrin, a large fortified settlement with Parthian and Roman phases of the 2nd and 3rd c. AD, on the east bank of the Euphrates.

Six silver coins minted in Caesarea of Cappadocia: Nerva, Trajan 2, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius. According to Pachomov they are coming from a destroyed burial ground. a plausible hypothesis as Kropotkin (2005) mentioned other similar coins found in graves (p. 267; nos. 1927, 1928, 1944).
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.no. 84974)

summary: 2830 silver coins: 2827 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 2 drachms: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 196-197); silver weight: before restoration: 9,290g; after restoration: 9,075.17g
disposition: History Museum ”Iulian Antonescu” Bacau, Bacau County, Romania

summary: The hoard was found in an ancient vessel and comprised between 500 and 600 bronze coins. Very close by, a large glass urn, pottery and three bronze basins were also found.
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknwon number of denarii found with an iron vessel. Only 14 denarii were identified: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) (AD 196-198).
86 denarii: Mark-Antony - Commodus (Crispina) (AD 180-191).
Over 26 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, Łódź, Poland (2 coins)

summary: Hoard of 87 aurei: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 7 aurei terminating in an issue of Trajan dating to AD 106. From 1826 to 1908, 7 Roman aurei were found by chance in the fields, all in the same region (Salzbrunnen and Z'underst Wyler), at a maximum distance of ca. 150 meters. These could be single finds or rather a dispersed hoard? Found in 1826: Nerva; 1859: Nero; 1894: Vespasian; 1896: Trajan; 1899: Nerva; 1907: Galba; 1908: Trajan.
disposition: Kantonsarchäologie Schaffhausen (4 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (2 coins); Bernisches Historisches Museum (1 coin)

summary: Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, bone artefacts.
Hoard of 89 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I - 3, Cotys II - 6, Rhoemetalkes - 11, Eupator - 69.
Unknown number of initial coins. 20 pieces - unknown metal - are kept in the Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (Ad 138-161).
disposition: Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 92 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver bracelet.
228 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina) (AD 177-191).
17 silver and bronze coins in Principia/barrack: 1 denarius, 1 quinarius, 2 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 6 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-138)
Nine denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).
The hoard comprised 36 coins including 33 sestertii (1 subferratus) and 3 dupondii terminating with issues of AD 191-192. All coins are worn, so this is most probably a 3rd c. deposition.
2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Regional museum, Chrudim, Czech Republic (now, missing)

summary: Around 1,200 aurei (according to Savio/Cavagna): Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Reported to have contained thousands of coins. The main part had been dispersed before the rest was confiscated.
A hoard of Roman denarii comprising at least 47 coins ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
9 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 80 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 67 sestertii, 12 dupondii, 1 As: Vespasianus - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Five denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).
A hoard of an unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. 44 coins were recovered: Republic - Trajan (AD 102).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
6 denarii found on the construction site: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
2469 denarii and provincial silver of which only 210 were recorded - Otho to Antoninus Pius (208 denarii, 2 drachms of Amisus of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius)
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara; Balıkesir museum

summary: 4 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Diva Faustina I, Lucius Verus (AD 163-165).

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).
3200 silver coins found with bronze cauldron: 3197 denarii, 3 drachmas Lycia: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161) . 10.8 kg
disposition: Museum ”Dr. Molnár István”, Cristuru Secuiesc, Romania (1965)

summary: Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.

A cultic area with two temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. One of the two temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 183).

A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.
Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just one hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard was found in a void within a Roman wall and comprised 5 sestertii: 1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius, 1 Faustina II (AD 147-176).

A deliberate deposit from the excavations at Ashwell. E Ghey writes: Group 2002 T215 (5) consisted of items in a 'placed deposit' in context 203. This deposit consisted of two copper alloy units of Tasciovanus, four copper alloy units of Cunobelin, one silver Icenian unit, a pierced dupondius of Claudius, an as of Vespasian and an as of Hadrian. The non-coin objects consisted of second century AD Roman objects (a brooch, mounts, numerous fragments of iron mail armour and implements, a fragment of a pipe-clay figurine) and part of a Bronze Age spearhead, in addition to fragments of pottery, animal bone and cremated bone. The as of Hadrian places deposit (5) in the second century AD at the earliest; a time in which the coin evidence as a whole suggests a reduction in activity at the site.

Hoard of 34 bronze sstaters of an autonomous (Agrippia) city and Bosporan kings: Aspurgus, Gepaepyris, Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Sauromates II and one issue of the mint of Agrippia Caesarea (Phanagoria).
disposition: Museum of Anapa, Russia (labelled as the "Gunyaevsky Hoard"; inv.nos. AM 10750/1-34)

summary: The hoard was found buried under a small heap of stones and comprised 22 bronze coins. Of these coins, 11 were identified as dupondii or asses of particular emperors. The others were not identified with any certainty, but were 'more or less recognisable' as issues of Vespasian or Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.
28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: 11 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 181).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 denarii were documented: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-19922).

Eleven coins found over three private searches; one in 2009, four in 2011 and six in 2012 (described as "being stacked"). The 11 coins are dated from Nerva to Antoninus Pius. It is not certain that all 11 coins are part of a hoard, but it is likely as they have been found within a small geographical area.
A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. Two bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
126 bronze coins: 88 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 8 asses, 1 provincial coin; 20 bronze coins unknown denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-161).
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest, Hungary (1897); inventory list no. 460/1896

summary: (?) 3 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).

A hoard of 59 plated Roman silver coins (cistophori and denarii), found on the south slope of the Acropolis in excavations by the Greek Archaeological Service, near the central room of the Eastern Roman cistern. Of the 59 coins, 35 could be identified: 16 cistophoric tetradrachms (Claudius – Nerva) and 19 denarii (Trajan – Commodus).
1,055 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (1,042 coins; inv.no. C 706); History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (8 coins); private collections (5 coins)

summary: Hoard of circa 350 silver coins. 26 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). A tetradrachm of Thassos (intruder?) were documented.
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
Seven denarii found through several rounds of detecting.
Unknown originally number of coins. 34 bronze coins: 21 sestertii, 13 dupondii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).

Hoard of 39 denarii, 26 glass and amber beads, several fragmentary specimens, and fragments of metal ornaments, including two silver brooches: Vespasian - Commodus. "Denarii are dated to the second half of the 1st century – the end of 2nd century AD, dating of the brooches, however, indicates that the hoard was deposited in the second half of the 5th century AD."
The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.
Hughenden - Upon Piggott Common: 24 Roman coins (copper) discovered 1795 in throwing up a bankan earthen vessel about 18 inches below the surface.
The hoard was discovered in 2013 within the boundaries of Vaukavyski County. Consisted of at least 140 denarii (Nerva-Commodus). The circumstances and exact location of the find are unknown.
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.

The coins were found in 1938/39 during excavation works on the west wall in the region of Geilenkirchen-Linnich (Kreis Jülich). 14 of the coins were lost. The remaining 21 ones are sestertii, ranging from Trajan to Commodus. All are very worn.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
Circa 350 republican and imperial denarii discovered. 79 denarii have been studied: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, Ploiești, Romania (35 coins), inv. nos. 920730-920761; private collection (44 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) two ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.
162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.
Funerary find: 2 aurei in a grave: Nero, Marcus Aurelius
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre des entrées, III, f. 114, nos. 3558-3559

summary: The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.
157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: Four aurei (Nero to Antoninus Pius) recorded at 4 different points in time, between 1996 and 2002, clearly forming a hoard. Many other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval.
The hoard was found in a burial which contained 'two middle bronzes of "Antoninus" and one of Faustina II, as well as a unidentified sestertius.
Hoard of 375 denarii. Only 7 coins were mentioned: Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Faustina II 3, Lucilla, Commode.
A find, comprising one aureus and seven denarii, was made at the south end of site XXVIII. The coins were found loose on the floor of a house of the Antonine period.
1243 silver coins: 1241 denarii, 2 drachmas: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 164)
Seven sestertii found sealing a child burial in one of the house of C. Iulius Silvanus: Domnitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-152).
Hoard of 100 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Five denarii found during survey in small area. Interpreted as small disturbed hoard.
700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
(1006) 978 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
The hoard comprised between 1,400 and 1,500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
215 denarii: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
The hoard was found during the 1988 excavation in the southern part of the Roman vicus. The coins (26 denarii, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius) were corroded together in a clump.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 40 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. X

summary: Found during excavations. Assemblage of 10 aes coins, Domitian to Commodus, in a roadside ditch, spread out over ca. 5x1 metres. The hoard comprised 3 dupondii and 7 asses.
Unknown number of aurei and silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only five aurei were seen: Trajan 4, Trajan for Plotina 1.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.
12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).
Group of 5 coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) as, Claudius I as, Nero 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised approximately 100 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. Only 7 were examined: Nero, Vespasian, Trajan 2, Hadrian 3.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain (7 coins)

summary: About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, two coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.
80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).

1,022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second one it was pretended to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just one hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: A farmer in 1864 found over 60 specimens of Roman silver coins during plowing on a small hill in the vicinity of Erfurt. 29 coins were described (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius).
A hoard of 74 denarii (Republic- Hadrian), found in 1854 approx. 1 km north of the place, 100 m from the street next to Dahnsdorf behind a hill in a ravine.

A hoard of about 400 Roman silver coins, found at Torfoot, 7 miles south-west of Strathaven, in a glass bottle, while cleaning a drain. Coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, wife of Antoninus, Crispina, wife of Commodus, and various other Emperors and Empresses, &c., all in good preservation, are mentioned. About fifty of the coins were so much verdigreated and adhering together, that they were broken with a hammer by a rude and unskillful hand, in order to separate them. J. Lindsay, View of the Coinage of Scotland (1845), 265, added Hadrian, Marcus, Caesar, Pompey and Crassus to the list of emperors etc. represented. The three last names may have been due to a misunderstanding of the legends on some coins. True Republican den. would be unusual in a hoard as late as the reign of Commodus.
Seven denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.

Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.

Four bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius), found on the Dowe-See estate on the Bullenteich in Braunschweig, next to other small Roman objects (bronze fibula, bronze ring, glass pearls, spindle whorl, etc.).
13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
6 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II (AD 145-175).
Hoard of at least 62 denarii. Only 13 are known: 8 republican among which Julius Caesar 1, Augustus 3, Hadrian 2.

Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
72 denarii: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 180-192).
666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
Hoard of an unknown number of Roman imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii produced some information: Augustus 1, Nero 2, Hadrian 1, 1 broken.
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
15 coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to NUMIS the tpq is around AD 180.
Unknown originally number of coins. 40 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
51 denarii: 16 republican, 35 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 119-122). Together was found a Dacian silver bracelet.
Hoard of 200 bronze coins: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

Eighteen Roman sestertii found close together by a metal detector user in the municipality of Gulpen-Wittem (in an area of ca. 1 m2). Two additional Roman coins (an as/dupondius and a coin of unknown denomination) were found within a ten-meter radius and can be part of the same hoard but certainty is lacking. The coins were reported in 2018.

Towards the end of October 1878 three aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A fourth aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.
14 Roman bronze coins and one autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6197-6234 (38 coins)

summary: 16 coins of Hadrian (AD 117-138). No further information.
Circa 150 bronze coins. Only 2 sestertii and 2 dupondii of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius were seen.
"About 100 tetradrachms and denarii together with a few dozen Roman coins (the latest being a fresh Hadrianic denarius...)" (Mildenberg 1984, 55).
Around 2,000 denarii found on the surface after the river outflow. Only 8 denarii were known: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Faustina I 3, Commodus 2.
31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 20 denarii were documented: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina (AD 161-180).

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
109 coins: 105 bronze coins, 4 silver denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163). Also part of the deposit were the head of a hair pin and a ring. Considered as a votive offering.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
(ca.30) 12 sestertii and dupondii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; auxiliary fund, inv.no. 693

summary: 40 denarii and 30 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Commodus (Crispina).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.
735 denarii found with ceramic vessel and a textile bag: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 195). Found together with a silver T-brooch within a Sarmatian settlement.
disposition: Numismatic Collection of the Institute of Archeology, Iași, inv. no. 323370 (the brooch)

summary: A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.
669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).
64 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
726 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 187-192).
28 sestertii: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Collection E.C. Lefèvre, Brugge, Belgium, in 1851 (28 coins)

summary: Hoard of 11 sestertii found adjacent to the large Cadeby hoard.
Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.
Hoard of around 2,000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

In 1884 a large hoard of Roman bronze coins was found in the area of Mindelzell. 30 specimens arrived in a private collection in Memmingen, of which 12 were later bought by the Memmingen museum. They are now lost.

A hoard of about 20-25 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by treasure hunter in the late 2010s between the villages of Pysarivka and Hrushkivtsi in the Vinnytsia region. The coins were found on an area of ca. 20x20 m and all had the same traces of bronze oxides. The finder did not provide a photo of the coins, but said that among the coins were denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius (including those with the rank of Caesar). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
A hoard of 30 Roman silver denarii, found at Waddow Hall, Waddington, and declared Treasure Trove. All the coins with the Lancashire Museums Service
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
The hoard comprised 185 coins, deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Six aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.
770 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
2 aurei of Domitian and Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).

A hoard of at least 24 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and possibly a silver fibula were allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s nearby village Semaki in Vinnytsia region. The coins were found in an area of 15x15 m. The silver brooch was found on the same area. Based on a photo of five coins, three of which were denarii from the time of Titus, Antoninus Pius and Commodus, one cast copy of a denarius with a portrait of Hadrian and an anonymous quadrans with a portrait of Mars on the obverse and cuirass on the reverse. While the denarii have general preservation and similar bronze oxides, the cast copy of the denarius and the anonymous quadrans are probably not part of the hoard. The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
Over 600 sestertii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 117-138.
9 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-130).
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.

A hoard of 161 aurei and 4 denarii was discovered on the site of 29 Klagenfurter Str. in Villach. Four aurei were initially discovered before a supervised excavation at the site uncovered the rest of the coins. Of the 161 aurei, only 100 issues dating from Nero to Septimius Severus have been properly catalogued. The four denarii have all been catalogued: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197).
disposition: Museum Der Stadt Villach (115 aurei and 4 denarii); private collection (42 aurei)

summary: Two coins of Antoninus Pius, one Marcus Aurelius and one of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.
Ten denarii (Vespasian - Commodus), found in 1872 during peat digging. Two thereof arrived in the Oldenburg archive; an additional three were noted in 1905 in private possession.

3,997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in two stages: 939 in 1965, 3,058 in 1970. In total: 3,663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).
10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.
The hoard comprised 16 denarii dated between AD 98/99 and AD 128/129.

A hoard of more than 3000 coins was found opposite the church in Baarlo in 1830. More than 3000 coins (32 gold and the rest in silver) remained with banker Wolters. Further data is missing. Description is known for 5 coins. The first publication, in 1838, mention coins from Augustus to the Antoninians.
ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Around 400 denarii found during archaeological excavations. Only 25 denarii provide information on issuers: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together with the coins was also a silver bar of 155g and, possible, a brooch.
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (25 coins)

summary: Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).
A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
15 aurei and 470 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Marcus Aurelius, found by a labourer at work in Rudchester grounds, while digging up the foundation of an old fence in 1766.
The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
A hoard of five bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.
500 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). TR POT XX IMP IIII COS III
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; circa 250 coins, inv.no. 853 1-128

summary: 22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing two aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in three layered rolls. They have been lost.
(50-60) 13 bronze coins: 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-155).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (13 coins), in 1808

summary: In 1925 a hoard comprising 1081 bronze coins, originally included in a pottery vessel, was found after agricoltural works. Coins inlcuded in this hoard returned to the finders and went missing, except for 1 sestertius of Didia Clara now kept in the Museum Bottacin in Padua. Only a brief report on the coins included in the hoard is now available.

The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.
(circa 400) 22 denarii: 2 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 105-107)
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 7 silver coins - 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 drachm - deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Several hundred Roman silver coins (coins of Galba - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius are mentioned), found during building working in Minden, in or before 1844. The coins were lost.

A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s.
