55 bronze coins with unknown findspot except for the mention north Portugal
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
Unknown originally number of coins. Six denarii of Marcus Aurelius were seen.
Four denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.
2 denarii: Commodus, 1 imitation of Marcus Aurelius; silver weight: 5.06 g.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and three silver spoons.

The hoard was found at a natural spring and comprised votives (including numerous wooden statuettes) as well as '149 copper coins of Roman emprors'. 79 of these coins were identified. The others were illegible.
A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.

In 1806, on the south-west side of Trinity Court, near the Turnpike Road, a hoard of nearly one hundred Roman coins was found. 79 of them were listed, ranging from the Republican period to Trajan. A few days after, a medal of Nero, and one of Antoninus Pius were found on the same spot. The Republican coins were certainly silver, but the metal of the others is uncertain.

Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, four treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by three treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.

6 denarii and 1 AE coin, ranging from Domitian to Commodus, found in cellar 207 between 1897 and 1908. These 7 coins of this find were not identified according to inventory number or type and could thus not be separated out from the list of single finds.
Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
Over 361 silver and bronze coins were found in five ceramic vessels. Only 191 coins were documented: 157 sestertii, 24 denarii were studied: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
26 denarii found in three separate finds (1921, 1924, and 1946): Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling two tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).
47 denarii: Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193); silver weight: 87.1-137.5 g
37 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No details on the structure.
11 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 2 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-179)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coins), donations P. De Baeck.

summary: 75 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
disposition: Museum of Southern Podlasie, Biała Podlaska, Poland

summary: 5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)
More than 188 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). 'Found at Avenue of the Sphinxes during clearance excavations.'
107 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Republic - Trajan (AD 112-114).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Lugo, Spain

summary: 24 denarii found ina lump of earth: Domitian – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver weight: 10.25 g.
68 coins: 67 denarii, 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196). Weight: 156 g.

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing a block of Roman bronze coins stuck together with corrosion products. Rever identified approximately 180 sestertii and 5 'middle bronzes'. The hoard was found by a labourer digging a hole to plant a tree.
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.
Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian
Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111). Weight: 68.27 g.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: Hoard of around 50 denarii. 21 coins were brought for examination by the finder: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown number of denarii. 933 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Silistra: Nero - M. Aurelius (AD 162-163).
37 sestertii found during rescue excavations. 32 coins were found in a ceramic jug and 5 next to it: Vespasian - Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius) (AD 180).
2 denarii of Hadrian
Seven aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).
76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
Fifty bronze coins were discovered in Roux, but only 9 were preserved, ranging in date from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius.
16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).

96 coins: 10 silver denarii, 1 quinarius, the other 85 coins are copper asses, dupondii and sestertii, and 1 unknown copper denomination. Other finds include 18 wire fibulae, a fragment of a bracelet and 1 unidentified artefact. Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 138-180).
15 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
disposition: Groninger Museum (12 coins), private collection (3 coins)

summary: (?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)
A potful of Roman silver coins. Only five coins have been poorly documented: L. Scribonius Libo, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina I, Faustina II, Commodus.

Two groups of coins, discovered in May 1989 while metal detecting on building ground at Elphinstone Road, Hastings. The first group of coins (92 bronze coins, Nero - Hadrian) were found with the remains of a pot and the second group (52 denarii found 'in a lump', with 7 later addenda, Republic - Hadrian) was about 40 to 50 feet away from the first. This may suggest successive deposits but they were treated as one find at the time. They have been split here. This record is for the silver coins.

129 bronze coins (120 Dium, 4 koinon of Thessaly, 2 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Ilium and 1 uncertain), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 1999). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.

In 1955 during ground work at a cemetery children randomly found a Roman hoard with a large quantity of coins. All coins except for the 10 described here (sestertii ranging from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) were dispersed. The true size of the hoard is unknown.
322 denarii are issued from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 193-195).
The total number of coins is apparently 1067 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 coins provide information on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.
8 bronze coins - 7 sestertii, 1 as - range: Galba- Trajan (AD 103-111) found in a ditch on the area of the Roman cemetery.
1,446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: 7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
At least 1381. Uncertain if all the coins belong to this hoard or they are contaminated from NIETULISKO MAŁE 1: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
disposition: State Archaeological Museum, Wrasaw, Archaeological and Ethnographical Museum, Łodz; Museum in Ostrowiec Świętokrzyskie, Archaeological Museum in Krakow

summary: The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel. Only 34 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Historical Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.nos. 98100-1; 036 658-1; 036 685 - 28 coins); Historical Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (inv.no. 12607/1-6 - 6 coins)

summary: 70 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
20 coins: 18 denarii, 2 bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
Circa 60 aurei. Disintegrated cloth bag found during excavations in the courtyard of a house.
Hoard of 50 denarii. Only 8 pieces are documented: Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus Pius Divus), Commodus 4.
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.nos. 14863, 14865-14869)

summary: A hoard of 60 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter at the end of September 2021: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). Photos of 45 coins were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters, Violity. According to the finder, the coins were in a “small pit”, not far from a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture, on the depth ca. 15-30 cm. At the end of 2021, the coins were sold at the Violity auction.

1590 bronze coins (1452 Dium, 47 koinon of Thessaly, 39 koinon of Macedonia, 13 Thessalonica, 7 Philippi, 2 Edessa, 2 Corinth, 1 Amphipolis, 1 Magydus, 1 Tralleis, 10 uncertain, and 15 Roman bronzes), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
(200) 41 sestertii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (41 coins)

summary: (3043) denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1453 1-349; 1466 1-8; 1468 1-25; 1470 1-352

summary: The hoard comprised 12 aes coins (sestertii and dupondii) ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius Caesar. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 5/1966) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (12 coins)

summary: 72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in two concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. Two further coins were found nearby.

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.
11 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2206

summary: 16 denarii (Galba - Hadrian) coins were found, covered with a terra sigillata plate, on Tiefenthaler Str.
5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: 28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken B contains 53 of the 217 denarii.
17 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 186-187)
disposition: Collection L. Eloy, Namur, Belgium (14 coins), in 1966

summary: A hoard of 19 provincial coins, found in grave T7 in the roman cemetery excavated at Strovolos. The coins are not described, but ill. pl. 18-19. They comprised 3 pseudo-autonomous coins of Thessalonica, 15 coins of Amphipolis from the Antonine period and 1 that remains to be identified.
180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
Only 4 sestertii are known: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
200 aurei: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Over 200 silver coins from Vespasian to Hadrian (Ad 117-138). No detailed information.
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are two denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: 78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla. No further details.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel. It comprised approximately 150 'large bronzes' likely to be sestertii. The hoard was discovered by a farm labourer on the plain of Saint-Rémy.
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.

Two denarii of Antoninus Pius, the first 'found on the Laleston by-pass road behind (SE. of) the Mackworth Inn', the second 'found during road widening on the Cardiff-Swansea road, near the A.A. Box west of Laleston'. One might suspect that both coins came from the same hoard, scattered by workmen somewhere near Laleston.
Around 800 denarii of wchich 189 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of uncertain number of imperial denarii found while metal detecting. 28 coins were presented to the museum: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
disposition: Grodno State Historical and Archaeological Museum, Belarus

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

The hoard comprised 2,077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: Seven denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.
A large hoard of 2,218 coins: Vespasian - Commodus. No further information.
271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Commodus (AD 184-185).
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).

Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and one imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

find_spot_name: CASTELNUOVO VAL DI CECINA - SAN BERNARDINO
summary: 102 coins found with the remains of a textile bag: 94 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Galba - Trajan (AD 112-114).
Originally 66 denarii, 55 preserved: Titus - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 155.21 g.
25 coins? "Medium-sized hoard. Allegedly Bar Kokhba silver and bronze together with Syrian tetradrachms and Roman denarii" (Mildenberg 1984, 56).

The first 20 (?) denarii from the hoard were discovered by schoolchildren in 1968, eight of them were transferred to the Coin Room of the Belarusian State University. V. Ryabtsevich tried to establish the place where the hoard was found, but to no avail. In the first hoard's publication the village of Žukievičy was named as its location. After that, at the hoard's place, amateurs conducted further searches for it. Separate denarii were found, two of which (Trajan and Antoninus Pius) were transferred by V. Kakareka to the Coin Room of the Belarusian University. The rest of the hoard was discovered by treasure hunters in 2011 near the village of Aliekšycy: 426 denarii and 18 fragments of brooches, which were donated to the Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus. Later, 10 more coins were transferred there. In total, 446 coins are known from the hoard (Vespasian-Septimius Severus).
disposition: Coin Room of the Belarusian State University (10 coins); Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus (436 coins)

summary: A small hoard of six Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about two years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in two years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as one deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).
The hoard comprised 117 sestertii and 43 dupondii or asses from Vespasian to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. It was found under the sixth step of a staircase discovered under a lime kiln.
More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins and 3 silver coins dated between the reigns of Vespasian and Hadrian.

From information obtained by Khaled Ben Rhomdane, the hoard comprised 2000 Republican denarii, although there is some suggestion that there were also imperial denarii including issues of Antoninus Pius. The hoard was stolen.
At least 9 denarii and 1 aureus: Trajan-Hadrian (AD 117-138).
115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: The 22 coins (sestertii, Trajan - Marcus Aurelius) are the remnants derived from a hoard of at least five pounds from a meadow (Eckenweiher) where Roman villas have been found. The find is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD.
10 denarii found within a cemetery together with other objects. The antoninianus (radiate) of Aurelian may be an intruder.
disposition: Initially in the collection of Councilor Scotti, later in the Museum of Wroclaw, Poland; today, lost.

summary: 13 bronze coins: 4 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 7 asses: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 64682-64694

summary: A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and Totengraben.
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: Eight denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. One additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver weight: 78.54 g.
317 silver coins: 313 denarii, (2 copies and 2 Lycian drachms) with a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 2001: Nero - to Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.
About 700 Roman coins were found in a ford in the river Pettarel near Carlisle in 1762. Coins seem to range from Nero to Faustina. A list of 64 of them (1 aureus, 62 denarii and 1 sestertius) exists.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found four silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
HER record of 30 to 40 denarii from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius found in the mid 1970s following dredging of the Little Ouse and not apparently recorded elsewhere.
Hoard of 35 Roman imperial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: M.K. Ciurlionis National Museum of Art, Kaunas, Lithuania

summary: The hoard comprised a total of 22 denarii dating from the Republic to Antoninus Pius. There are no further details about the structure of the hoard.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (22 coins)

summary: Circa 100 Roman coins, silver and bronze. Only, 2 denarii of Antoninus Pius and Faustina I and 5 bronze coins (Vespasian to Trajan) were known.
7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
22 denarii found on a cultivated field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174).
disposition: Gabinet Numizmatyczno-Sfragistyczny, Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, Wrocław, Poland

summary: 50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river two miles from the estuary. The six preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.
The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised '27 aurei of Vespasian to Commodus along with some silver denarii.' The gold coins were distributed amongst the family of the landowner. Although 9 of the aurei were given to the Musée de Rouen by M. Esnault, these were later stolen.
disposition: Musée de Rouen, France (9 coins. stolen)

summary: A hoard of 243 Roman imperial denarii and their barbarian imitations was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2017 or early 2018 in the Sumy region. On January, 11, 2018, information and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the coins were allegedly found in his vegetable garden (a common formula of Ukrainians treasure hunters to conceal information about the place of discovery). Photos of the coins have not been preserved. Forum experts have identified the coins as “standard”, singling out only separate coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (for Faustina II and for Lucilla) and Didius Julianus. In January 2018, the coins were sold in several lots at the Violity auction.
The hoard comprised 2 aurei from Antoninus and Faustina II and 5 denarii from Trajan, Antoninus, Faustina I, Faustina II and Lucilla. It's probably a part of hoard.
103 denarii, among which one imitation: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 181).
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: 11 AR denarii to AD 122. Latest coin is type of Hadrian-Fortuna referring to the departure of the emperor on his great expedition, AD 121-5. RIC assigns date range of AD 119-122.Addenda of 3 AR denarii to 117 in 2014 included here.
110 denarii found in the Principia from the legionary fortress: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, Austria (108 coins).

summary: Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and one more denarius found in 2009. Most likely one owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
5 coins found scattered near a disturbed grave within a cremation necropolis: Hadrian 1 as, Antoninus Pius 4 sestertii (AD 152-153).
Unknown originally number of coins, around 160-200 denarii. Only 90 were documented: Otho - Clodius Albinus (AD 195-197).
Report in BM file with information from Suffolk county Council on a group of 7 or 8 coins, only three readily identifiable. Details of the latter only were received.
Unknown initial number of coins. 145 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 178-191).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; private colection V. Heisu from Parava (145 coins)

summary: Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
A hoard of one denarius of Divus Antoninus Pius and one Roman Provincial coin of Marcus Aurelius minted in Edessa, found in grave 22 in the western cemetery in Pella.
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only six provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
44 denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Found together with a silver brooch dated between the end of the 4th century beginning of the 5th century AD.
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 95 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Pertinax (AD 193).
Hoard of 700 silver coins. 578 pieces were recovered: 577 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Pokrajinski muzej, Celje, Slovenia (578 coins); dispersed

summary: Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A group of 27 coins, together with a further silver coin fragment. Addenda of 3.
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)

5 bronze coins (Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius), found dispersed across the excavation area. It is possible that an Augustan as (RIC 436) also belonged to this hoard. One interpretation is that these coins could have belonged to a small 'hoard' (or purse) that was later scattered across the site, though admittedly there is no sign of other artefacts being moved around the site.
Leather purse with 10 bronze rings and 11 bronze coins: Trajan - Antoninus Pius. Only one bronze coin of Antoninus Pius is known.
46 bronze coins: 45 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2287-2326

summary: The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
The Cheshire HER lists "A small hoard comprising a silver denarius of Faustina II (AD 176), two unidentified Roman bronze coins and a bronze dolphin-type booch datable to 1st to 2nd century AD".

About 40 aurei were found by a peasant while he was digging, he also found a Hindu temple. This is the earliest recorded find of Roman coins on Indian soil. The hoard seems to have consisted exclusively of second-century coins.
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
324 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
310 denarii found with two leather bags placed in a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 1996-2000 hoard: Nero - Pertinax (AD 193).
2 denarii - Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I and Marcus Aurelius found together with 4 gold bracteates.
The hoard comprised an unknow number of aurei, at least 12(?), from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 136).
Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver weight: 38.41 g.

The circumstances of discovery and the composition of the hoard were judged to be suspect. De Vesly questioned whether this hoard might actually have been stolen and assembled as a hoard. However, there is nothing to support this hypothesis. Found by a workman in a quarry in the Duclair forest: Nero - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Two or four coins are missing.
A hoard of 18 denarii (Otho-Commodus) found during excavations at Dura Europos, in E4-15.
17 denarii: Titus - Hadrian (AD 117).
(8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)
Hoard of 314 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Initially, circa 2,050 coins. Only 1,938 enter in the museum collection: 270 republican denarii, 1662 imperial denarii, 5 drachms, 1 as: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166). Found with a bronze jar.
60 denarii found, probably, with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Unknown initial number of coins. 91 denarii in the Regional History Museum in Pleven: Otho - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 975 1-70

summary: The hoard comprised a large number of Roman coins which were shared out between the finders. Fournier compiled a list, suggesting that 39 were of Nerva (and Trajan?) and 42 of Hadrian.
8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)
The hoard comprised 2 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (1 Antoninus Pius), Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous Commodus), found in grave 4 in Sevasti.
Hoard of 15 imperial denarii found with a jug in an inhumation grave: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
Some silver coins found in a garden. Only one denarius of Hadrian and one of Commodus were documented.
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
Circa 150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii are known: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I (Diva) 1, 2 uncertain issuer.
181 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 491.23 g. Found together with sherds and animal bones.
30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: 2 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Trajan, Antoninus Pius; silver weight: 5.57 g.
Three denarii found in a funerary urn together with an amber bead and a wire link ring: Domitian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (Divus) (AD 180).
121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
53 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 156-157).
disposition: Zemaljski muzej Bosne i Hercegovine (National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina) Sarajevo (32 coins) - 1981

summary: (ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: 70 imperial bronze coins of poor state of conservation. Among them, issues of Antoninus Pius 12, Faustina I 1.
(32) 2 denarii: Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)

A hoard of at least 70 Roman Imperial denarii was discovered in 2018 (?) in the vicinity of Fastiv. Information about the hoard on the treasure hunting forum Violity was posted on 16 December 2018, probably by its finder, who also provided one general photo of the deposit. The coins were fused into one large ingot and had traces of heavy exposure to fire. Three coins were found separately. A silver item in the form of a ring-bent bar measuring ca. 2.5x3 cm (possibly a clasp from the pouch in which the treasure was hidden). There were also small fragments of pottery nearby, whose relation to the hoard is not clear. Judging by the photos posted on the forum, the hoard was sold at the Violity auction. The further fate of the deposit is unknown.
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.

The Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale acquired 36 aurei on 17.03.1847 (Reg. C, nos. 1982-2017) and a further 44 on 8.2.1848 (Reg. C, nos. 2117-2160). 79 remain (with one swopped in 1939). The Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers bought 6 aurei on 3.4.1847 and 2 on the 13.06.1847, with fragments of the vase acquired on 04.03.1849 (Reg. I, p. 53-54, no. 209, p. 58, no. 217, p. 74, no. 269). They were stolen in March 1885.
Hoard of 320 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Pertinax (AD 193).
240 silver coins: 228 denarii, 2 drahms found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 8

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a seven year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).
29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
Two aurei of Vespasian and Trajan, probably, found in Braga.
2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: 63 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: Sold; Local museum Olevsk, Ukraine (3 coins)

summary: 91 tetradrachms of Alexandria in a small pot found during excavations. Range: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: 12 in London, 5 in Oxford. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
Around 50 bronze coins were found in a money-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: 21 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 AE (copper or brass) found in the neighborhoud of a Roman building next to some clay sources.
(50) 25 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found together with a silver bracelet.
A find of 45 Roman denarii (Otho - Antoninus Pius) was made in a garden in Vicht. The coins were found in charcoal residues.
Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.

A mixed hoard of Syrian tetradrachms, Cypriote tetradrachms / didrachms, and denarii, ranging in date from Nero to Hadrian. One coin of Vespasian is countermarked by Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-180), which is why the closing reign is given here as Marcus Aurelius.
378 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).

The hoard comprised 60kg of sestertii mixed with some middle bronzes (2,500-3000 coins). Only 26 sestertii and 1 dupondius were preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 98-117). The hoard was found by a worker, planting a vineyard.
disposition: History Museum, Louresse-Rochemenier, France (10 coins); finder (17 coins)

summary: Originally, 1,500 denarii and a drachm found with a clay vessel. 1,391 coins preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 3,924.6 g. (1.391 coins).
180 sestertii, for 109 the issuers are known: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt (95 coins); 5 in Prfratbesitz; Museum St. Veit an der Glan (12 coins); 5 private collection, Austria

summary: 257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
Hoard of 125 denarii. The large majority belong to Trajan including the title DACICVS. The hoard was found with two silver vessels embedded each other.
Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only two coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: 27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Three aurei are said to have been found by Landrat von Weyhe. These might be the remnants of a gold hoard. Apparently, there was another aureus found at the place.
The hoard comprised 301 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 300 were of Nero with a single coin of Hadrian. They were acquired in Egypt by Dattari.

The hoard comprised a total of 1,133 coins, including 1,031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
40 bronze coins were discovered with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 have provided some information: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

A hoard of ca. 850 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found at Amheida (Dakhla/Dakhleh oasis) in area 4, divided in three textile bags, on top of a mudbrick debris layer filling pit F90, immedialely adjacent to the temple of Thoth.
23 denarii, group of single finds, found within a settlement: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 57.89 g.
The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
Unknown originally number of coins. 43 denarii are kept at the town museum in Piatra Neamț, Romania: Republic – Antoninus Pius (AD 147-148).
disposition: Town museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (43 coins)

summary: 7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.
16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: 52 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 135.15 g.
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).
Unknown number of silver coins. One denarius of Trajan and one of Hadrian are kept in the museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 9, 553

summary: A number (possibly 150) of Roman silver coins (possibly Nero - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius), found in the vicinity of the Herren-Holz, a quarter of an hour north of Spahn, lying on a mound of earth.
Hoard of at least 46 denarii: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoard from Strunga.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (25 coins)

summary: Two denarii found above ground in 1921, assumed to have derived from a ditch dug at the site.
8 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as, 1 AE: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
21 denarii: Galba - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 14845-14865 - in 1944)

summary: 20 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only eight pieces were recovered: 2 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 3 asses: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).
115 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 354 g

"In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including one of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. Two of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
The hoard was discovered near the village in 2011. Consisted of 13 denarii (Trajan-Pertinax). The circumstances of the find and the place of the coins storage are unknown.

A small hoard of 15 Roman imperial denarii and one Lycian drachm: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was found in April 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information and general photo of the coins of the hoard were published on April, 29, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. By the treasure hunter himself, the hoard was called the “purse of denarii”. The coins have a fairly good preservation (weak wear). In early May 2017, the coins were sold at the auction Violity and their fate is unknown.
7 aurei: 6 Hadrian, 1 Sabina (AD 132-134)
disposition: Museum of Iron Gates Region Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania

summary: 160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.
600 denarii. 361 pieces were examined: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138); silver weight: 669.3-1389.9 g.
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
14 Alexandrian coins: 13 tetradrachms, 1 drachm: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: 6 denarii to AD 161 - "hoard 2" Davies 2000. From an occupation layer in range 3 of structure 1, Pickfords Garage site. Scattered in a small area with no evidence of a container.
Around 400 denarii found with a clay pot. 338 coins are known: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (294 coins), Museum Sandomierz (8 coins), Museum Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski (12 coins), Poland

summary: During the excavation of the Roman town, 2 small hoards of both silver and bronze were found from below the front of site VI. Hoard A comprised 23 coins, ending with Hadrian.
Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry stones. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
12 denarii entered the collection of the Pedagogic High-School in Iași: Vitellius – Hadrian (AD 125-128). Part of the hoards Strunga I and II.
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 9 pieces were recorded: 7 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Claudius I Commodus (AD 184).
Group of 2 dupondii: Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II (Diva) (AD 175-180).
21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.

453 denarii from Nero to Commodus (AD 180). The latest coin has the reversed inscription as: TR P V IMP IIII COS II P P. The composition of the hoard is described by D. Tacchella (1896) by of number types not by the number of coins (!). There are 224 types: Nero 1, galba 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 21, Titus 4, Domitian 9, Nerva 4, Trajan 13, Hadrian 34, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 54, Faustina I 23, Marcus Aurelius 30, Faustina II 12, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 5, Commodus 1, Crispina 1.
disposition: Some of the coins entered the National Museum in Sofia in 1895.

summary: 38 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 192).

83 bronze coins and (silver coins?) found in a marble rock. There is some information on 28 coins: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The three denarii may not belong to this hoard (Dembski 1977).
disposition: Museum Carolino Augusteum, Salzburg, Austria (26 coins); Prähistorischen Staatssammlung, München, Germany (3 coins?)

summary: 35 denarii found among stones: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only two coins are preserved

A Roman burial was discovered in the spring of 1929 in widening the south side of the Ashford-Maidstone-London road. This almost certainly represents an untouched cremated deposit. Together with other objects, it contained 18 gold coins or disks.

c. 1400 coins, mostly aurei, of which only 45 specimens were recorded, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius (43 aurei, 1 denarius of Nero and 1 of Galba), found during illegal excavations in Kuşakkaya.
disposition: Adıyaman museum; Kahramanmaraş museum; private collection in Ankara

summary: (200) 17 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 11-180).
In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks three bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.

A hoard of about a 100 Roman bronze coins, found on the estate of Carstairs house (= Monteith House). Nero, Trajan, Faustina, Germanicus, M. Aurelius, M. Antoninus are mentioned. To this hoard belonged 13 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781 (Trajan, Hadrian, the Empress Faustina, and Germanicus, are mentioned; the coin with Germanicus probably refers to an emperor Germanicus in its titles, e.g. Nero, Domitian or Trajan). No coins from this hoard have been located in NMAS, Edinburgh, or in Hunterian Museum, Glasgow. There is, however, in the University archives a letter from Mr. W. Fullerton, Carstairs House, dated 20 Oct. 1781, to Dr. A. Stevenson stating: "I send you a small box containing a dozen or more bronze medals intended for the College. About a hundred or more of them were found together by some workmen in repairing a road to a miln near this place [i.e. Carstairs House]. {...} They are cheifly [sic] Trajans Hadrian Antoninus Pius two or three Faustinas and one Marcus Aurelius Caesar and several others which from the inscription being much worn out their age cannot be so easily ascertained tho' on comparing them with Vallaint's [Vaillant's] Numismata they seem to be of Domitian. The place where they were found is about a quarter of a mile from an old Roman encampment or station [i.e. the Roman fort at Castledykes] of which part of the vallum remains still partly intire."
The hoard comprised 45 silver tetradrachms from Claudius I to Antoninus Pius. It is not clear whether the coins represent a complete hoard or part of a hoard.
7 asses: Domitianus - Hadrianus (AD 121-122).
The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.
35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).

13 Roman silver coins, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, in 1781, all dug up 'with a great many more' in the muir (= moorland) of Linlithgow. These probably came from a find of 300, found in the Burrowmuir, deposited in an earthen urn.
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 denarii entered Museum Collection in Opole in 1973:
disposition: Municipal Museum Opole, Poland (40 coins in 1973)

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 200 coins. 13 were shown to the local archaeological society: 6 were 'frustes', 6 of the Antonine family (including Faustina I and II) and one depicted a wolf. Bizeul states that they were all coins of the High Empire. Sanquer suggested that the coin depicting a wolf was a fourth century nummus, but reverse types of the Antonine period also depict the wolf. The three coins of Antoninus Pius and 2 of Faustina given to the museum by Gauja 'found in Rezé in 1851' are likely to come from this hoard. The hoard was found during the building of the east-west road through the city.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.
18 denarii were discovered in the vicinity of the village of Raksha. Fifteen were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 192).
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them two imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).
Unknown originally number of aurei. Forty-five coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. Seventeen coins were studied in detail. Nine coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.
403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.

A hoard of 47 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) was discovered at the end of 2021 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Mikhail Tabachko (Михаил Табачко) on December 14, 2021. The finder reported only that the coins were found together somewhere in the Lviv region. The coins are well preserved. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 27 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan – Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”V. Parvan”, Bucharest, Romania (27 coins).

summary: (62) 10 denarii of Tajan (AD 112-114)
Circa 300 denarii were discovered while plowing. Denarii of Antoninus Pius and Commodus were mentioned.
A Regensburg employee submitted 8 sestertii (Antoninus Pius to Commodus) to the prehistorical state collection. The coins were derived from a find of unknown size in Regensburg.
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being two sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
124 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-189); silver weight: 43.80 g. (16 coins).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 7 sestertiiare known: Trajan - Commodus (AD 181).
16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

A hoard of ca. 460 Roman silver denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius for 344 of them, the others are lost), found in an earthenware container 1 1/2 feet under the soil while removing stones ('Steineroden') in the heather, at Wassermühle on the Wingstberg.
Two aurei were found on the banks of the Paleru river.
Five 2nd century AD bronze coins, found in the area of the town hall.
It comprised 200 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Commodus (AD 180-192) found with a ceramic vessel.

151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.

The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.
IARCH record for a hoard of five denarii of Septimius Severus in a small conical lead-alloy container.
Unknown originally number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Three coins are known: Hadrian denarius, Septimius Severus denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate).
1,365 silver coins: 1361 denarii, 4 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Elagabalus (AD 219).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania Bucharest (Inv. no. MNIR 189402-190766)

summary: A hoard of 15,000 - 20,000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: 43 kg = +8,000 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 258)
24 antoniniani (radiates) and 42 imitations found in the basement of a Roman villa: Gallienus - Maximian I (AD 285-291).
The hoard was found in the northeast part of the Roman fort during an excavation campaign in 1983. It comprised 4 aurei and 70 denarii, ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
A hoard of ca. 800 silver and 20 bronze coins, found in a pot while ploughing a field (at Hermendonk?, not far from Wachtendonk). The coins are not preserved, but a list of emperors exists.

A hoard of 124 coins, comprising tetradrachms (Philip I - Gallus), denarii (Domitian - Alexander Severus, one quinarius (Caracalla) and one provincial bronze coin (Gordian III & Abgar), found at Dura in G1, during the season 1936–7. No container was reported.

Two antoniniani (radiates) of the brothers Macrianus II and Quietus, placed on either side of the head of the deceased, and a coin (pierced) of Caracalla minted at Paphos, placed over the chest. Burial cave.

Mints: Rome (332); Nicomedia (11: Elagabalus); Antioch (6: 1 Caracalla and 5 Gordian III); 3 copies of Gordian III. Silver: 139, 213 coins; Silver weight: 462.0-912.5g The hoard was found during levelling works at a sawmill.
Hoard of 96 bronze staters of Rhescuporis V (AD242-267).
5 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Valerianus I (AD 253-260).
34 aurei found with a ceramic vessel and jewelry: from Nero to Trajan Decius (Hostilian). Includes a medallion of Gallienus; gold weight: 238.2-255.2 g.
The hoard comprised 114 sestertii: Trajan-Gordian III (98-243 AD).
See hoard IARCH-4FC580 for details of the find. This record has been created for the coins from pot 2.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing a silver finger ring with blue glass setting depicting a figure left and 380 radiates from Gordian III to Postumus. 267 examples were catalogued by Pinsard. A closing date of AD 268 is given by a APOLLINI CONS AVG reverse of Gallienus and 7 coins of Postumus with ORIENS AVG with P in the field reverses.

The hoard was discovered during antiquarian exploration of a Gallo-Roman site. It appeared to have been originally stored in a cabinet measuring 6 feet square and comprised more than 300 base-silver coins. According to the finder, villagers who knew the findspot continued to find coins in abundance there. 300 silver coins: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 76.1-710.8+g.
circa 150 denarii, 30 preserved. Nero-Seveus Alexander (AD 227). 1 nummus of Constantius II is an intruder.
1,124 denarii: Nero - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
The hoard was found in an iron cooking pot or 'marmite' and comprised an uncertain number of silver coins and some jewellery, such as 'large finger rings'.
58 antoniniani, ranging from Caracalla to Volusian.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only eight silver coins are known: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Caracalla – Gallienus (sole).
189 antoniniani (radiates) found together in the theater of Caesaraugusta: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Work in progress.

The hoard comprised two ceramic urns that contained more than 100kg of Roman coins (according to Payan-Dumoulin) or 40kg (according to Vallentin) equating to approximately 12,000 coins. Only 4,685 coins, all radiates, were catalogued: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 3241.0-14999.1 g.
The hoard comprised 1,000 antoniniani (radiates) dating to the reigns of Victorinus and the Tetrici. Only three coins were described.
Rescue excavation undertaken by the archaeological service. 20 antoniniani and 3 denarii, ranging from Caracalla to Gallienus (sole reign) were found.

The hoard was found whilst dredging the marshland close to the railroad from Saint-Omer to Calais. Silver: 1636 (1450) antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver weight: 442.7-2044.0 g.

In 1958 a small collective find of 18 antoniniani ranging from Aurelian to Carinus Caesar was unearthed in a ditch during excavations conducted by the commission for archaeological exploration of late antique Raetia.
Unknown originally number of coins. According to I. Mira there are 2,842 coins known, all antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
disposition: Museo del Seminario de Santiago, Braga, Portugal (68 coins)

summary: The hoard, found with a bronze vessel, comprised approximately 1,200 radiates from Claudius II to Diocletian (AD 287-288); silver weight: 133.5-237.1 g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing numerous antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Gallienus, Claudius II and Tetricus I.
4 coins of Gordian III: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii P M S COL VIM (AD 238-244).

In 1978, Mr. Charles Pire, a coin dealer from Brussels, bought about 500 pieces from a lot of 972 coins found in the region of Amiens. It consisted generally of about fifteen antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Salonina, a dozen of Postumus, a hundred of Victorinus, around 20 of Claudius II, about 300 of Tetricus I and II from the mints of Trier and Cologne. Other 30 pieces consisted of imitations of Tetricus I, large module. 235 coins are presented in detail: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-273); silver weight: 185.7-1213.9 g.
disposition: Private collections: Ms. A. Wattecamps; Mr. S. Genvier; Mr. J.-M. Doyen; Mr. Pire

summary: Large hoard of 160 denarii found in Præstemosen ("the Priests Bog") in the town of Gudme, close to a pond. The hoard had been totally ploughed up.
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins. 29 coins are kept in the Joanneum, Graz. According to G. Dembski the coins may rank from Severus Alexander to Gallienus.
2,060 silver coins: 1,849 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 209 antoniniani (radiates), 1 drachm: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-252).
disposition: History and Archaeology Museum Constanța, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised 2,445 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani-radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I (AD 257) found in a lead container.
Unknown number of coins found with a pitcher. Among the coins were noticed 2 of Claudius II and 2 minted in Carthage for the Vandals king.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus' joint reign and Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269. FMRL suggests that it was a small part of a much larger hoard.
The six antoniniani (radiates) were interpreted as representing a purse hoard or being part of a larger deposit.
The find comprised a bracelet set with four third century coins.
The hoard comprised 42 bronze coins from Nero to Gallienus including imperial bronzes (sestertii) and Provincial bronzes from Knossos, Kydonia, Koinon of Crete and Alexandreia Troas.
(500-600) 142 denarii: Vespasian - Balbinus (AD 238); silver weight: 771.6-1621.0 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coin); collection L. Renard-Grenson (113 coins), Liège, Belgium; private collection (22 coins).

summary: (?) 51 sestertii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
7 coins: 4 denarii, 2 sestertii, 1 bronze found a in a layer of fire: Antoninus Pius - Severus alexander (AD 222-228).
(200+) 103 silver coins: 78 denarii, 25 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 246)

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing '30 silver and bronze coins, including 1 of Nero. It is possible that this hoard is the same as the hoard of large and medium bronzes of Domitian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Gordian III which were examined by Deville.

There were 914 antoniniani (radiates) in the hoard. The obverse details for each coin were not recorded and it is not possible to assign the coins to mints. Although Mira (1995-7, 137) gives the total number of coins as 914, only 905 are accounted for in the catalogue.

One drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Julia Domna) and 78 antoniniani (radiates) (Julia Maesa to Gallienus), found in the northwest-west suburb of Kerch. 71 of these were published by N. Kunina in 1962. To these, Golenko adds a further 8 antoniniani.
19 antoniniani (radiates) of Aurelian. Unpublished.
119 coins: 1 denarius, 118 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-259).

The hoard was found in 1973 during archaeological program. The archaeologists discovered 45 kg of sestertii, in 12 rolls in a wood box. It comprised c. 1980 sestertii from Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) (AD 253-268).

The hoard comprised 2000 coins of 'copper, silver alloy and silver'. In the report compiled by P. Ilarregui the hoard contained pieces of the emperors: Pius Gordianus, Philip, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Gallienus, Saloninus (Caesar), Saloninus (Emperor) and Postumus. A small selection of 10 coins was sent to the Real Academia de la Historia.
disposition: Real Academia de la Historia, Madrid, Spain (10 coins)

summary: 572 silver coins: 2 denarii, 570 antoniniani: Macrinus - Valerian I (AD 253 -259); Silver weight: 1143.8-2361.7g
(Circa 20) 17 silver coins: Elagabalus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1832 1-17

summary: 114 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus I (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. inv.no.741-758, 760-766,768-770,772-780, 782-842, 845-855, 982

summary: 142 coins in two vessels containing 71 sestertii from Titus to Septimius Severus and 71 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Gallienus. Only 54 were recovered and studied: 30 sestertii, 24 antoniniani (radiates).
6.6 kg of coins, 2110 or 2400? antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II/Postumus (AD 268-270) silver weight: 570.7-2636.5 g.
17 coins: 16 denarii, 1 dupondius: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241); silver weight: 23.9-44.2 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruzelles, Belgium (1 coin); Collection H. Verlooy of Vilvoorde (16 coins), in 1967

summary: 28 antoniniani found during a fieldwalking: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256).
Hoard of 198 coins of the Bosporan kings, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes (AD 266-278).
Large hoard. Only 25 silver coins are known: 9 denarii, 19 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 32.6-59 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3343

summary: The hoard comprised 'a large number of bronze coins, apparently in gold or silver. Fourteen were identified as issues of Aurelian.

The hoard comprised 152 coins of which 128 were studied by Dancoisne. There were 12 sestertii and 116 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), although Dancoisne does not specify which coins are which! The hoard was found by workmen by the side of the river: -116 coins; silver weight: 34.0-336.1g.
The hoard comprised 117 bronze coins dated between Ptolemy I (323-283/2 BC) and Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

Within lumps, the coins were arranged in stacks shifted sideways, 389 silver coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates). All coins were covered with a light green patina. There are 88 denarii: Clodius Albius to Gordian III and 301 antoniniani (radiates): Macrinus Valerian I and Gallienus).
Unknown originally coin number. 5 antoniniani (radiates) and 87 denarii are known: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised one silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.
Hoard given to Sfax Museum in October 1961, examined by Salama: 36 antoniniani: Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole)? (AD 260-268).
(5000+) 14 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274)
758 imperial and provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 42288-46046

summary: Assemblage of 95 Roman coins (1st century BC to 4th century AD) and eight Roman objects submitted as a potential Treasure case (the objects were considered unrelated to the coin hoard). Those coins and objects were found within 50 yd radius on a possible Roman site beside the projected course of Ermine Street with the aid of a metal detector.V. Drost writes; "Among this assemblage are 66 copper alloy sestertii and sestertius fractions which could possibly be part of a hoard. The coins range from Vespasian (AD 69-79) to Gordian III (AD 238-44) and the composition is very similar to that of the Cowbit Hoard (BM ref.: 2003 T76). Most of the coins are dating to the 2nd century AD and are extremely worn as a result of an extended circulation until the deposition of the hoard well into the 3rd century AD. However, some of the coins struck under the Antonine dynasty are in a fairly good condition and it cannot be assured that all of the coins were originally part of the hoard. Eight silver denarii dating to the 1st and 2nd centuries AD could potentially be part of the hoard as well, even if hoards mixing silver coins and copper-alloy coins are not common. Nevertheless, it is difficult to ascertain that each one of those coins belong to the hoard. Note: a gold aureus of Trajan was previously found nearby.On the other hand, the 20 radiates or nummi dating to the 3rd and 4th centuries AD are very unlikely to be part of the hoard and can reasonably be considered as single finds." (Unpublished catalogue).The denarii of Augustus and Vespasian are plated.
10 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Claudius II to Probus (276-282) found in a grave.
79 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II part of a larger hoard?
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 133 sestertii studied from a total of 300 found: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 2543-259).

A hoard of 788 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus), denarii (Julia Mamaea) and antoniniani (Caracalla - Gallienus) found during the excavations at Dura Europos, in a jar under the embankment beside the Palmyra Gate.
A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: 3rd century. Roman fort at Watercrook S of Kendal was excav by Potter in 1975-5. In square stone guard chamber to NE gate of fort, one charcoal rich layer sandwiched in between two occupation layers/phases of use contained a 'large quantitity of objects' incl. pottery, bronze finger ring, arrowhead, calthrops, iron lock & building fittings, a surgical probe, & 4 coins close together. These dated to post-AD 268-273, & were of Claudius II, radiate copies of Victorinus, & Tetricus I. T.W. 1979. Romans in North-west England. Excavations at the Roman Forts of Ravenglass, Watercrook, and Bowness-on-Solway, pp. 158-160, figs. 60-61.
A hoard of 40 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB, VB/C, VC and VI), found among brocken crockery on the floor of the kitchen of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
3,428 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy pitcher: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 922.5-4265.3 g.
disposition: Museo Civico «Ala Ponzone» di Cremona, Italy

summary: 26 silver coins: 17 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 251); silver weight: 35.5-53.2 g.
The four coins appeared together in the west corner, belonging to a room structure erected with walls of opus vittatum.

Four coins (Syracuse, Augustus, Tiberius for Agrippa and Severus Alexander), allegedly found in the bed of the River Weser at low tide, at 'der Tiefer'. FMRD has listed this find under Bremen-Mahndorf, but doubts that it is genuine.
98 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria found with a ceramic vessel: Probus - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 291-292). Briefly examined by Martin Price.
431 coins: 295 denarii, 136 antoniniani: Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver weight: 584.0-1024.5 g.
(+1000) 92 antoniniani: Gordian - Valerian I (AD 253-259
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (63 coins); dispersed -1981

summary: (+500) provincial bronze coins. 37 pieces entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

A hoard of 97 tetradrachms (Nero–Severus Alexander), 25 denarii, and 1 antoninianus, found in a trench excavation at Gindaros. As no further excavations were done araound that trench, the archaeological context remains so far uncertain.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 300 coins have been examined by Dr. Haralanov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 5 tetradrachms (Trajan-Caracalla) and 1 denarius (Faustina II).
860 billon tetradrachms: Marcus Aurelius - Claudius II (AD 268-269) found during excavations beneath the floor of an underground room of a house.
disposition: 849 in Ann Arbor. The rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: (c. 3000) 1831 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 811.0-3749.0 g.
Initial quantity of silver coins: 13 kg, Studied: 9 kg (Gerov, B.) = 1790 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 2238.1-4652.9 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 843-856 (1716 coins, stolen 1407)

summary: Hoard of circa 200 coins. Only 17 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered: Trajan Decius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259).

170 bronze coins: 83 official, 87 provincial of Alexandria (Domitian - Maximian I). During excavations in this region, where many Roman settlements are known, this lot was presented to de Looz by the mayor of Hannut.
Around 800 denarii found with a copper alloy vessel: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
NMR record of 6 coins of Probus found in a field at Seaham and given to the Newcastle Society of Antiquaries. No further details.
67 antoniniani discovered in a room with hypocaust of a Roman edifice: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised 214 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Gordian III which are today lost. Also found in the excavations as isolated finds were a denarius of Septimius Severus, and 2 bronzes of Severus Alexander. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 313.3-487.1g
127 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Carus (AD 282-283) found on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 102 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: 294 bronze coins: 292 sestertii, 2 small bronzes, found with the fittings of a wooden box: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-244).

A hoard of 30 coins (2 uncertain, 1 Imperial Roman; 27 provincial coins: Dion, Odessa, Pella, Koinon of Macedonia, Thessalonica, Cassandrea), found in a grave in Sindos in 1981, ending with coins of Philip.
Originally between 80 and 100 coins were found of which only 2 aurei and 16 denarii were retained: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 214).

summary: Unknown number of bronze coins. 5 pieces were examined: Caracalla - Elagabalus.
Circa 2,000 denarii but only 20 pieces indicate emperors from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax.
12 silver coins: 4 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 16-26.8 g.
Bizeul described 5 antoniniani (radiates) found in Quénet which may be part of a larger hoard or perhaps the contents of a purse.
(619) 607 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 235 imperial denarii and 371 antoniniani: M. Antony to Trajan Decius (AD 249-250); silver weight: 775.8-2053.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 13

summary: A hoard of 1985 denarii (Nero-Julia Mamaea); 310 drachms of Arabia (242 of which depict Arabia and 68 show a camel, some overstruck on Nabataean kings); 1 Caesarean drachm (Domitian); 31 tetradrachms of Antioch (Nero-Hadrian); 2 Lycian drachms (Trajan); 2 Amisus drachms (Hadrian), found in a village near Amman.

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 Roman coins including denarii, dupondii, asses and radiates terminating in a single issue of Postumus.
The Musée de Rouen has preserved 25 coins from this find, initially, it consisted of 33 antoniniani (radiates).
