summary: Initially 805 antoniniani (radiates). 786 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 268). It included issues from the mint of Siscia, but the number is not given. Data for other mints was not recorded.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 2 asses are known: Nero, Gordian III.
10 provincial bronze coins. 1 of Septimius Severus, 1 of Caracalla, minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis.

The hoard comprised 9 gold coins: 1 multiple of 6 1/2 aurei, 8 aurei: Trajan (Plotina) - Florian (AD 276). Together were found jewelry: small gold male bust, three old bracelets, three gold armillae, rolled gold band, jet (or black glass paste) bracelet, black material bracelet, six small jet (or black glass paste) pieces, bronze pin.
12 provincial coins ranging from Commodus to Philip (Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedononia) found in grave 8 in Methone.
1200 denarii found in ceramic vessel. 156 pieces entered the museum collection in Svishtov: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the courtyard of House L in Insula 27 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 5 denarii of Maximinus dating to AD 235-236. The excavation archives provide no further details about the circumstances of discovery.
43 silver coins: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 61.6-125.1 g.
The hoard comprised an 'unknown number of sestertii and 12 silver coins of Gordian III': Nerva - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
1,680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver weight: 2151.6-3837.1 g.

60 silver and bronze coins found by workers 19 provincial bronze coins were aquired by the Varna Archaeological Society: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
10 coins found at Schrotzbug, which is a medieval castle on the Schienerberg: 1 dupondius, 2 aurei and 7 denarii, ranging from Titus Caesar to Severus Alexander.
190 coins found with a pot: Gordian III - Carinus (AD 283-285).
29 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
Only 303 antoniniani (radiates) are identified. The exact findspot is not known, but it is possible that it comes from Oudenburg, Gistel or Torhout: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown initial number of coins. 20 silver coins: 19 antoniniani, 1 denarius: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight of 25.1-49.1 g.

summary: IARCH record for a scattered hoard of 6 denarii. Other coins have been recorded from the immediate area but they were not considered to be part of this hoard. For full details and images see SOM-D0A907.

The hoard comprised 57 bronzes dating to the second and third century AD. Sherds of pottery were recovered at the same time as the hoard suggesting that it was originally stored in a vessel. The hoard was discovered in a molehill. Although mentioned in numerous publications, it has never been studied in any detail. It was kept by the Club archéologique d'Auzances.
700 radiates The hoard was bought by H. Rigaux, but doesn't appear to have gone to Lille Museum with the rest of his collection.
A hoard of 8 Roman Provincial coins from the mints of Thessalonica, Edessa, Pella and the Macedonian Koinon from the period AD 222-235, found in grave 52 in the western cemetery of Pella.
The hoard comprised 11 sestertii: Hadrian-Philip I (117-246 AD).

summary: 1,447 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximianus I (AD 293-294).
980 antoniniani (radiates) found in two lots, in 1962, 1980, in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar/Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 272).

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy spoon and 147 copper-alloy coins from Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Julia Mamaea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip II.
The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
90 silver coins: 23 denarii, 67 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 125.5-252.4 g.

About 800 denarii (Mark Antony to Caracalla) and fragments of a possible ceramic container found by workmen digging a ditch near Bron-y-Berllan farm. The original size of the find is uncertain; Davies (1929) records that the workmen who made the find pocketed an unknown number of coins, and that the remainder of the hoard was split between the British Museum (18 coins) and the Verney family of Bodelwyddan Castle, Anglesey. The size and condition of the hoard cannot be accounted for until 1918, when only 333 coins were transferred from Bodelwyddan to the Bangor museum. Robertson's examinations of the hoard in 1937 and 1948 identified 350 coins split between Bangor and the British Museum; the whereabouts of the remainder are unknown.
disposition: Storiel Museum, Bangor (c. 300 coins); British Museum (18 coins)

summary: The coins were found during the rescue excavation of a villa: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
One barbarous imitation of a Roman gold coin found in a grave together with a denarius of Augustus coin of Caius and Lucius and a plausible drachm of Gotarzes II.
Said to have been found at Satala. The hoard comprised 17 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Carus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 11 silver coins in the Museum of Ruse: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 16.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1495 (initially, 12 coins, after robbery only 8)

summary: 20 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD were find during metal detecting activity. No further information
A hoard of 428 denarii dating from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (235/236) and one Caesarean drachm of Septimius Severus found at Sulakyurt.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkez

summary: Found whilst digging a ditch in the Saint-Louis or Quatre-Acres cemetery (the ancient cemetery zone). The hoard was not found in a burial context. 662 bronze coins: sestertii, and dupondii or asses: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.
247 antoniniani (radiates): Gordiasn III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

disposition: Institutul de Cercetări Eco-Muzeale, Tulcea, Romania; inv. nos. 49.717-49.816

summary: Group of 6 coins (silvered antonini) stuck together into 'a column', with a 7th found close by, found in topsoil just outside of apse of bath house in commander's praetorium/principia in Bowes Roman fort, excav. by Hartley & Frere in 1966-67. Latest coin an issue of Constantinus II of AD 332. Coins may have been originally wrapped in linen (in Shotter's coin report). Topsoil above a rubble layer containing pottery, wall plaster, iron nails & building stone, but no other topsoil finds mentioned.D. Shotter, The Roman coins. In Frere, S.S. and Fritts, R.L. 2009. Excavations at Bowes and Lease Rigg Roman Forts, pp.56 to 66. Yorkshire Archaeological Report No. 6, pp. 39.The radiate of Tetricus is given as RIC 100. The coin of Victorinus is listed as a copy. Shotter excludes the nummus from this group.

The hoard comprised more than 30 'large bronze Roman coins. TAF speculates as to whether it is an entire hoard or part of a larger hoard. Found in a gravel quarry.32 coins were donated to the museum by M. Caille: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-69).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Inventory: III, 2, p. 78, no. 2005 (5.11.1908).

summary: The hoard was comprised a black pot containing 356 denarii and antoniniani (radiates)
24 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 67360-67382

summary: The hoard comprised 300 'minimi' which were very difficult to identify. One article suggests that it was possible to read the names 'Tetricus, Antoninus, Aticus, Constantinus etc' on some examples. Mandin confirmed that the hoard was of barbarous radiates, probably of Tetricus.
67 silver coins: 21 antoniniani (radiates), 46 denarii: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: 11 antoniniani: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
26 antoniniani (radiates) found with traces of textile recipient: Aurelian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: Laboratory of Restoration of Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Roma (inv. nos. 508899-508924)

summary: A small hoard of 13 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Maximin I Thrax (AD 235-238) was discovered in October 2018 in Crimea, probably in its eastern part. Information about the find and a general photo of the coins were published on 21 October 2018 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder himself identified the coins as “purse of denarii”. The coins have a very good preservation. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
(750) 639 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 937.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 468-1108 (641 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 79 sestertii from Vespasian to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).
15 radiates (Gallienus to the Tetrici) from a larger hoard of unknown size discovered while ploughing a field somewhere outside Fishguard. No further details are available.

3,000 to 5,000 silver coins, ranging from Augustus to Severus Alexander, found while digging gravel close to the Jever castle, on the city moat. 2,200 coins were melted down, the rest dispersed. Zedelius published 564 coins attributed to the hoard.
disposition: Oldenburgisches Landesmuseum (part); Schloßmuseum Jever (part); Ostfriesisches Landesmuseum, Emden (part); Münster museum (part)

summary: 18 antoniniani (raddiates) found in the dump of the ancient quarry: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing several thousand (more than 4,000?) coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus 'all in silver, with varying titles'. A list of numbers of types (rather than numbers of coins) exists. The coins were discovered 'by chance' in ancient ruins at the site. Silver: 4000+ (480) coins; Silver weight: 921.7-10397.2+
disposition: Musée d'Orbigny (20 coins), France; Musée de Guéret, France

summary: The hoard comprised a large greyware 'olla' filled with small bronze coins, totalling approximately 2,000. These were partially dispersed although 500 coins were studied by Janicaud and 137 examples donated to the Musée de Guéret. No coins of the Gallic Empire were found in this hoard. The hoard was found when a farmer's plough struck a vessel.

During groundwork a coin hoard of 310 coins was unearthed near the Roman fort of Gunzenhausen. It comprised 308 denarii and 2 antoninianii, ranging from Commodus to Gordian III. Note that FMRD lists 310 coins, but in the summary only gives 309.
Unknown initial number of coins. 313 silver coins went to the Museum of History in Silistra, Bulgaria: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria (313 coins); inv.nos. 5584-5896

summary: The hoard comprised somewhere between 2,000 and 2,500 coins, of which a large proportion were taken by the finders. Only 308 coins were catalogued.
Unknown initial number of coins. 69 bronze coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
497 bronze coins: 496 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Venezia (252 coins)

summary: (700) 160 silver coins: Trajan - Valerian I/ Gallienus (AD 253-268). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring.
1,489 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a heap on the floor of the underground room N during excavations of a house.
500 antoniniani (radiates): Probus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).

On road construction activity a hoard of 300-500 denarii was discovered. Coins of Vespasian, Domitianus, Traianus, Hadrianus, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Septimius Severus and Severus Alexander were noticed.
1,456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 394.1-1819.1g.
The hoard comprised 'some 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which only 20 were examined' Found at the ancient port in unknown circumstances.
32 silver coins discovered in a small ceramic vessel: 7 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2574

summary: Five coins from the Trajan Decius reign were discovered by treasure hunters in 2011. The exact location and circumstances of the find are unknown. The coins have traces of fire, therefore, they may have been found in a burial (cremation).
523 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293) found in a jar, hidden in a hole dug out beneath the floor of underground room H, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 507 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 200-300 denarii of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD found in unknown circumstances. No further information.
A hoard of 11 antoniniani (Valerian I to Postumus) was found in the Schwemmerstraße.
277 antoniniani (radiates) and 29 imitations (28 radiates and 1 denarius): Severus Alexander - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
41 coins: 39 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 57.5-75.2g.
The hoard comprised 2394 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses Galba to Gordian III (AD 238-239).
The hoard comprised 300 coins of Claudius II, along with finger rings and intaglios intended for finger rings. Found in a sewer.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: (160) 130 silver coins: 129 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 239); silver weight: 181.8-353.2 g.
3 kilograms of coins. 154 entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 28.3-191.4 g.
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1118-1133

summary: The hoard was found in two ceramic vessels hidden under some large stones. It comprised more than 8,500 bronze coins of which 7,978 (Hucher) or 8,117 (Lallemand) radiates and copies were identified. Callu estimated that 5.2% of the coins were imitations. The hoard was found during stone quarrying under some large stones: Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); Silver weight: 1517.4-14518.3
The hoard comprised 1,200 aurei from Hadrian to Elagabalus together with 16 artefacts of silverware. Two amphorae found close to the surrounding north enclosure of the Precinct of Amun-Ra in Karnak.

2,154 silver coins: 45 denarii, 2,109 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260); + 6,669 provincial bronzes: 3,600 Callatis, 3,000 Tomis, 6 Histria, 5 Odessos, 21 Marcianopolis, 13 Nicopolis, 8 Hdrianopolis, 6 Anchialos, 3 Dionysopolis, 3 Mesembria, 1 Pautalia, 1 Bizantion, 1 Augusta Traiana, 1 Nicaea.
1,141 silver coins: 546 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 5771

summary: 26 coins: 24 sestertii, 2 denarii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235); silver weight: 4.75 g.
disposition: Collection Ms. Ausselet, Charleroi, Belgium (26 coins and the lid)

summary: The hoard comprised 'a large quantity of 3rd century coins, of which 39 were given by M. Richard to the Musée de Laval (Mayenne): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 12.5-46.8g. Three coins, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax and Saloninus are lost.
(130) 79 coins: 3 denarii, 4 antoniniani, 71 provincial bronze coins: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

A hoard of 159 provincial bronze coins (Septimius Severus to Philip I) and 73 illegible coins, found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 14, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).
6 antoniniani (radiates) found in a small ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 2 Probus 2.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 1,440 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Of this total, 1,424 were catalogued by Chanel. Silver: 1358 coins; Silver weight: 246.9-3528.5g
Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). 352 coins were recovered: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
Over 3,000 billon coins of Alexandria offered for sale in Cairo to Dattari. "Many Aurelianus, some Claudius and perhaps 1/4 Gallienus." Yje sale did not take place.
4 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Provinciaal Utrechts Genootschap van Kunsten en Wetenschappen, Utrecht, Netherlands

summary: Contents of a little purse. Six denarii Septimius Severus - Caracalla.

The hoard was found during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' at Troussepoil and comprised 231 brass coins (sestertii?). Close to the hoard, 3 broken black ceramic jugs were excavated, two of which were filled with ashes and funeral pyre debris. Baudry thought that the coins had originally been placed in the jugs, but that hypothesis is not certain. The hoard was discovered during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' of Troussepoil.
The hoard comprised over 1,000 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. 640 coins have been seen: Titus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a total of 130 coins including 6 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius and 124 Roman Provincial coins from Athens dating to Periods V and VI (Hadrian to Gallienus). This hoard is linked to the invasion of the Goths in AD 267. It was found 300 m north of the archaeological site of Eleusis.

A hoard of 1,702 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Clodius Albinus to Trebonnianus Gallus, found in the surroundings of Düren approx. 15 years before 1930 when it was published. It is not sure that the 1,702 coins listed there encompass all the coins that were originally part of the hoard.
1014 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised some broken vessels containing approximately 4,000 bronze coins which were thought to have mostly been sestertii.
270 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 70 antoniniani (radiates), 200 sestertii. 107 coins were examined: 16 antoniniani (radiates), 91 sestertii: Trajan - Marius (AD 269).

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 368 coins including denarii and sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius and Provincial bronzes of the Koinon of Thessaly from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus I. It was accompanied by some pieces of gold jewellery.
disposition: Éphorie des antiquités préhistoriques et classiques de Larissa

summary: 47 silver coins: 4 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Caracalla-Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 70.4-108.5 g.
Originally, 201 silver coins. 190 silver coins are documented: Hadrian - Carus (AD 282-285). The half follis of Justin I/Justinian I is, most likely, an intruder.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 165 (190 coins)

summary: A hoard of 64 provincial AE coins of Ionia, Lydia, Caria, Thrace, Macedonia and Cilicia, dating from Antoninus Pius to Salonina. See also Klose, Smyrna, p. 123 (2 specimens, and not 1 as mentioned in Noe).
Four kilos of silver coins - 2,457 denarii and 2 drachms ranging from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus (AD .
Part of a larger hoard. 17 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1701-1718

summary: The hoard comprised between 600 and 700 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 210.9g and 874.1g.
41 silver hoards: 2 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus (Julia Maesa) - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 260-268). The coins were found together in a small pit.
A small deposit of 10 coins: 9 sestertii, 1 antoninanus (radiate): Vespasian - Carus/Carinus for Magnia Urbica (283-285). The last coin, possible, intruder.
c. 4000 (2244) antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 720.1-1079.9g.
2 denarii: Septimius Severus, Severus Alexander (AD 222-228). Possible part of LIPA 1937
14 silver coins: 13 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 20.8-37 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2247

summary: (?) 39 antoniniani: Claudius II -Diocletian (AD 293-294); silver weight: 7.1-12.5 g.

The hoard was found at a very shallow depth placed under or on a flat, square stone. It comprised a vessel containing 3,369 coins. J. Chappée bought the hoard and compiled a catalogue of 3,075 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations. M. Amandry undertook a new study of the hoard in 1983 and compiled a catalogue of 3,052 coins. It is this catalogue which is recorded in our database. Silver weight: 784.8-3627.8g.
A hoard of 233 Alexandrian tetradrachms, ranging from Nero to Philip, found 1968 in Abu al-Gud, in the vicinity of Luxor.

M. Poilly donated a lot of 173 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) to the Societé archéologique de l'Orléanais' which were found 'in the environs of Dieppe': Maximinus I Thrax - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 44.4-232.4 g.
The hoard comprised 110 Roman bronze coins from Augustus to Gordian III with a tpq of AD 239.
105 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 31173-31277

summary: 100 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13604/1-100 (100 coins)

summary: The hoard was discovered in a burial and comprised 38 radiates from Gallienus to Tetricus II. An as of Augustus was also recovered which may be intrusive.

The hoard comprised a total of either 5027 (according to Vlachogianni) or 5044 coins (previous reports). These include radiates from Caracalla to Gallienus and Salonina and 1 Roman Provincial bronze of Augustus from Sparta.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1,500 and 1,800 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 sestertii of Divus Antoninus Pius, Severus Alexander and Postumus.
43 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 206-210). Found together jewels and dices embedded in a wall.
117,000 ”bronze coins of the 3rd century”, weighing about 38 kg, buried in a pit sealed by tiles. Probably, they were intended for re-minting.
disposition: Institut national de recherche archéologique préventive

summary: Around 20 provincial bronze coins are known. Seven pieces were documented: Septimius Severus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
157 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 43.5-370.6 g.
disposition: Collection Huybrigts, Tongeren, Belgium, in 1902; destroyed by fire in 1914

summary: Hoard found in a cooking pot (not preserved) during construction work for the Nordostbahn railway track. It comprised an unknown number of antoniniani, of which 204 (possibly the greater part) are preserved in public collection, ranging from Trebonianus Gallus to Claudius II. - After the publication in 1992, at least another 6 coins from this hoard were recorded, in a private collection in Diessenhofen. The sherds of the pot are described in the 1893 publication. Four Gallienus coins were also subjected to chemical analysis at the same time, pp. 11-12: "Derselbe hat drei Stücke auf ihre Zusammensetzung quantitativ und qualitativ, das vierte nur qualitativ untersucht und folgendes gefunden: I. 6 Theile Zinn, 94 Theile Kupfer; II. 30 Th. Silber, 0,3 Th. Gold, 69,7 Th. Kupfer; III. 18 Th. Antimon, 82 Th. Kupfer; IV. Kupfer, Antimon und wenig Bismuth."
disposition: Thurgauisches Historisches Museum, Frauenfeld (158 coins); Museum Allerheiligen, Schaffhausen (40 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (6 coins); private (6 coins)

summary: Hoard of 12-15 kilos of coins - 5,500 pieces - found with a ceramic vessel. Only 270 were recovered: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Cludius II (AD 268-270).
3 coins: Vitellius sestertius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate) (AD 244-245).

Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel while ploughing. 32 pieces (denarii, antoniniani, provincial bronzes) entered the museum collection in Shumen: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1507-1537, 1546

summary: 300 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 130 coins were recovered: Vespasian - QuintillusI (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised a grey-blue ceramic vessel containing 217 antoniniani (radiates) from Trebonianus Gallus to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 66 g to 270.3g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic container holding less than 40 antoniniani (radiates). A radiate of Trajan Decius found at the same findspot is likely to be part of the hoard: Trajan Decius - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
ca. 40 coins in a leather purse, but only 5 coins are identified: Septimius Severus (1), Postumus (4).
250 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 10 coins have been seen by T. Gerasimov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The total number of coins found is not known although it is suggested to be as 5,000 pieces. Only 251 coins kept in a local collection were studied. Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(3500-3600) 3106 antoniniani: Trebonianus Gallus - Tacitus (AD 276); silver weight: c.640.1-4436.6 g
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,507 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275); weight: 6,100 kg.

Around 550 antoniniani (including an antoninianus of Pacatianus) were found by metal detecting. The coins were placed in a ceramic vessel and another ceramic vessel serving as a lid. The coins were sold without documentation. Ten coins came into possesion of H. Nowak: Valerian I 5, Gallienus 3, Salonina 1, Valerian II 1 (AD255-258).
20 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 18 sestertii: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 350 silver coins, 'nearly all debased coins.' The coins included issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Geta, Plautilla, Macrinus, Diadumenian, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Maximus, Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius and Herennia Etruscilla. Piette mentions a coin of Diocletian but this is an error for Diadumenian.
Two radiates (Gallienus and Victorinus) found along with a gold ring beneath a stone in the valley side around Blaen-cwm-Pennant near Llangynog. No other information is available.
21 coins discovered within the ruins of a Roman settlement. 11 pieces in the museum of Targovishte: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

36 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Balbinus and Pupienus (Gordian III Caesar) - Claudius II (AD 270-271) found in a jar, placed upright with its top just beneath floor level in a corner, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 32 in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: 31 coins: 29 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii found together: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
54 antoniniani (radiates) found in a wall with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer mentioned these coins in particular: one of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and one of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
276 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver weight: 387.6-713.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (3 coins); May 1967, 273 coins and the vessel

summary: The hoard comprised 14 Roman Provincial coins, found in grave 11 in Methone: Dion (1 Elagabalus), Edessa (1 Caracalla, 1 Julia Domna), Thessalonica (1 Geta, 1 Commodus, 2 Elagabalus, 1 Julia Maesa, 1 Philip I), Pella (1 Julia Mamaia, 4 Gordian III).
24 large bronze cooins (sestertii and double sestertii?): Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
19 AE sestertii and fractions to AD 242
Over 1,001 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Marcus Aurelius - Diocletian (AD 288-289) found stored in a heap at the foot of a stairway leading to the second floor, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 995 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 14 sestertii found in a house: Nerva - Philip I (AD 244-249).
6,442 silver coins: 6,395 denarii, 47 antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); weight of 21 kg.
The hoard comprised 22 silver coins from the reign of Macrinus (AD 217-218).
The hoard was found in "Perron" locality, in a vase. It comprised 1,200 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised 8 to 9 kilos of coins. Magaud catalogued 2,406 coins: 1 denarius, 2,405 antoniniani (radiates) and in 1910, the abbot Angot added another 43 coins which Magaud incorporated into the hoard. The hoard was found by a farm labourer in a field: Maximian I Thrax - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 651.7-5724.2g.
7000 antoniniani up to AD 270. No further information.
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins, almost all of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
67 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Diocletian (AD 284-293).
866 bronze coins together with 4 billon coins ranging from Gordian to Hostilian.
disposition: National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sarajevo

summary: 449 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
The find comprised numerous (1000-2000) copies of radiates of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Few hundreds of provincial bronze coins. 92 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 26923-27020 (92 coins)

summary: This hoard comprised 3,727 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of c. AD 265-275.
Two provincial coins, minted in Alexandria (Diocletian and Maximian), found on a field in ca. 1900.
Circa 150 antoniniani (radiates). 77 coins, including 24 copies. Together was found a small bronze hatchet: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c.35.0-156.5g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (collection Thaurin), France (77 coins). Hoards file in the Archives of the Museum (no inv.nos)

summary: 601 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
386 denarii: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 231).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12359/1-36 (36 coins)

summary: 600 imperial and provincial bronzes found in a ceramic vessel during excavation work. Dr. Harlanov has examined 384 pieces: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).

53 antoniniani (radiates) were found on Hosenstraße 4-5. They were purchased in 1903. "The coin series is so unified that it seems reasonable to accept it as a small hoard; the state of preservation is especially uniform."

The hoard comprised an urn containing 218 (or 318) Roman silver coins, both denarii and antoniniani (radiates). A silver statue depicting a 'wise old man' was also discovered at the same findspot a little later. The hoard was found by a farmer called Filliol while working in his field; silver weight: c.60.4-563.7g.
136 silver coins: 74 denarii, 62 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver weight: 38.3-350.5 g.
disposition: Collection E. De Breyen (67 coins), in 1881; Town museum, Ieper, Belgium (vanished in 1914)

summary: The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
200 antoniniani, most of them belonging to Gordian III, were found beneath a collapsed roof within an ancient settlement.

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel covered with a tile. It comprised 12 very worn 'large bronzes' of the High Empire (Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander etc) and approximately 400 denarii and radiates including issues of Severus Alexander (one or two), Maximinus, Gordian III (numerous), Philip, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian II and Salonina. The majority of the coins were very corroded. The coins were accompanied by seven gold intaglio finger rings and two gold necklaces, one set with emeralds and the other lozengiform blue stones.
"Few hundreds", only 89 were seen: Balbinus - Maximian I (AD 294).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80313, 54 coins)

summary: Approximately 800 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered of which 750 were recorded: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Portugal

summary: Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 96 coins were described: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
180 bronze coins: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
(c. 200) 112 coins: 110 antoniniani (radiates), 2 bronze copies: Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: c.53.5 g.
The hoard comprised 50 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found on the Arcellier property, but dispersed almost immediately.

Funerary find. 'A large number of coins finds' between large Stone blocks. Near the place were found human bones and funerary inventory. The 30 coins analyzed revealed antoniani of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus and Claudius II (AD 268-270). No further Information.
disposition: Society of Natural History Savoie (30 coins)

summary: Around thirty antoniniani in freshly minted condition, of Gallienus, Macrianus, and other contemporaneous issuers.

A hoard of 103 Roman imperial denarii: Otho – Caracalla (AD 211-217) was discovered by two treasure hunters in the mid-October 2009 in the Kyiv region. The first report about the hoard was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on October 26, 2009, and on October 29, November 2 and 23 photos of the coins were published. According to one of the finders, initially, not far from the unexcavated earlier pits from other treasure hunters, 71 coins were found on an area of 5x5 meters with a depth of 15-20 cm. At a later time, on the findspot was made sondage and the next 19 coins were found, and later – a further 13. The coins were cleaned by finders. The preservation of the coins is mostly good to very good. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
9 sestertii found within the south-west district: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 247).
6 coins: 4 bronze republican (!), 1 denarius Nero, 1 antoninianus (radiate) Aurelian (AD 270-275).

In 1852 a hoard of antoniniani from the middle of the third century was discovered in the neighbourhood of Klugham. 31 specimens from the hoard fell into the possession of the Historischer Verein von Obb. 33 coins are listed in FMRD, including 2 denarii (Caracalla - Valerian).
(c. 300,000) silver coins: 1 denarius, 4,463 antoniniani/radiates: Marcus Aurelius - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
404 silver coins: Commodus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of History, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1483

summary: The hoard comprised more than 35,000 antoniniani (Aurelian - Diocletian, all dating from before the reform of AD 294), found off the coast of Syrna at cape Fteni Punta. The hoard was found on a shipwreck (Syrna I) and has been interpreted as carrying wages or money for military expenses. The hoard was first found by a sponge diver, rescue excavations followed in 2002.

A small hoard of 9 antoniniani: Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early September 2022 possibly near the town of Bar in the Vinnitsa region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity September 16, 2022. The conditions of discovery of the hoard are unknown. At the end of September 2022, five of the nine coins were sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the other coins is unknown.

During the excavation of Roman fort at Reculver, a rectangular sunken room, poss. the strong room of the principia & sacellum, was excav., 23 ft 10 in. long & 20 ft wide. It had a thin skin floor of white mortar, covered in a deposit 6-12 in. deep of loam, mortar, painted wall plaster & domestic refuse, incl. pottery. It also produced frags. of 2 stone inscriptions from commemorative tablets, 6 iron arrowheads, & 21 coins of Antoninus Pius to Constantine II, with 14 from period AD 260-293. The rubble layer above contained mortaria, roof tile & box tile frags, & may represent collapsed roof, & this layer produced another 4 coins of Postumus of AD 268.Philp, B. 2005. The Excavation of the Roman Fort at Reculver, Kent. Kent Monographs 10. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 44-45
A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.
88 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Commodus - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
196 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valentinian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 245.0g.

The hoard comprised a black ceramic jug containing 8,500 coins (22kg). A list of types that would interest collectors was produced. Fillon notes that coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Claudius II made up the majority of the hoard and that were about 20 coins of Aurelian. There was a radiate of Victorinus with a IOVI CONSERVATORI reverse copying an issue of Aurelian in that it reproduced the officina mark P for Milan. The hoard was found by a farmer in his field. The vessel was kept in the Collection de Rouchebrune. Fillon bought the coins for the Soc. Antiq. Ouest.
Unknown initial number of coins. 169 (but there is evidence only on 161 coins) bronze coins were studied: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 266-267).
Nine antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
A hoard of 243 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, including 5 Eastern coins of Septimius to Geta and one uncertain of Severus Alexander.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkey (inv.no. 1861)

summary: (+485) 472 silver coins: 106 denarii, 366 Septimius Severus - Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257/258. The coins were minted at Antioch (5 coins), Milan, Rome and Viminacium but data concerning the number of coins from each mint was not recorded. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 598g to 1241.7g. The coins were accompanied by eight pieces of jewellery: a tubulus, part of a chain; a conical tubulus, part of a chain; the fragment of a bracelet; a fragment of a bracelet; three parts of the coil of a bracelet; a piece of semi-circular sheet-metal, part of a chain.

The hoard comprised 53 Roman bronze coins (sestertii?) from Galba to Elagabalus. A coin of Maximian I was also found but this is thought to have been a stray loss, rather than being part of the hoard.
6.7 kg of antoniniani, of which 2,125 pieces entered the museums in Sofia and Vidin: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1079 (1990 coins); National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 8130-8264; 8679-8696 (153 coins)

summary: 48 coins: 13 antoniniani (radiates), 16 denarii, 17 sestertii, 2 asses: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

Hilltop settlement. The hoard was found during metal detectorists' surveys next to many single finds. It comprised ca. 50-60 antoniniani (ca. Claudius II to Postumus), which were partly melted down and fused into a lump. A few types are visible: PAX AVG, MARTI PACIFER(O) and FELICITAS AVG.

The hoard was found as the result of deep-ploughing which brought 126 small Roman bronzes to the surface which were collected by farmers. An archaeological excavation then revealed a greyware vessel filled with more radiates and a further pink ceramic vessel containing 1,276 coins. Two containers, one with 988 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Domna to Postumus, the other 1,437 from Valerian to Tetricus II Silver: 2,425 coins; silver weight: 730.8-3581.8g.

A hoard of 46 mostly bronze coins (26 provincial and 20 imperial), ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius, found scattered on the floor of Villa A, in a destruction layer associated with the Sassanid invasion.
+100 coins dating from Philip I to Valerian and Gallienus. No catalogue was made and no further information given about the composition of the hoard.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 151 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 41.7-187.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 327, 2 coins)

summary: A Roman coin hoard was found in the field of a sexton containing more than 100 silver and copper coins, with most of the silver coins made of bad alloy. The sources mention coins of Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Gallienus, Salonina, Aurelian and Probus. Four coins are listed in FMRD, of which a description exists. It can be assumed that the hoard comprised mostly antoniniani of the middle of the third century AD and was buried between 276 and 284 A.D.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel in a layer of fire. 28 denarii survived: Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Gordian III (AD 241-243; silver weight: 44.4-85.4 g.
56 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
1269 silver and bronze coins: 1251 denarii; 7 plated denarii; 9 antoniniani; 1 drachm; 1 bronze: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1777.1-4207.8g
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: Large hoard found while ploughing. Only 13 antoniniani identified: Caracalla 7, Philip I 6.
IARCH record for a small hoard of 10 radiates. Possibly associated with the Chalgrove II hoard (IARCH-CB9058) but recorded separately due to uncertainty over this association.
41 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274) found in a savings box.
At least 1,772 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy jug: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 287-288).
148 Roman coins and silver and brass jewelry. 126 coins: 6 silver coins, 116 sestertii and 4 dupondii/asses: Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249)
39 silver coins: 1 denarius, 38 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (39 coins)

summary: 56 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2069

summary: 488 silver coins: 227 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 260 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised more than 6000 radiates from Julia Domna to Postumus, the most numerous being of Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Found by a workman on the land of B. Flamand
3,501 antoniniani: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Quietus (AD 260-261).

A scatter of coins from the hoard were found by a farmer. A systematic investigation of the findspot by Mr. Pioger and Térouanne recoverd a further scatter of 800 coins as well as excavating 3 vessels containing 3,600 coins (radiates and copies): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282). A catalogue of 1,941 coins was prepared by R. Boissel. In addition, there were 2,500 imitations and minimi. The coins were dispersed in June 1976, although some of the imitations were preserved in particular collections. A small portion of the hoard was found by a farmer. Following its discovery, there was a systematic investigation of the site. Silver: c.3600 (1941) coins; Silver weight: c.271.1-1874.1g
103 coins, range: Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus. No further details.
The hoard comprised approximately 300 radiates of which 64 survive.

A hoard of Syrian tetradrachms (668 according to Coin Hoards, 666 according to Bland) ranging in date from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus. It is said to have been found at Iskenderun, 57 km north of Antioch.
Four coins (two denarii and two antoniniani, Septimius Severus - Gallienus), apparently found together around 1845 on a field between Stegelitz and Fehlitz.
Hoard of 191 coins: 190 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 Roman provincial coin (Ephesus) found as a pile on the caldarium's floor: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 272).
NMR record of a small radiate hoard of 8 coins found whilst building a house in Keighley in the late nineteenth century.
4 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 3 sestertii were found with fragments of a 'terra nigra' pot. The sestertii were found above (ca. 30cm) the coin hoard.
220 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
4127 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 1261.0-5249.0 g
disposition: Musée d'Annecy, France; inv.no. 3477 (3828 coins); 400 coins dispersed

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. antoniniani recovered: 1 Gordian III, 3 Tranquilina (AD 238-241).
158 coins: 7 denarii, 151 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21275-21281 (7 denarii); inv.nos. 5224-5376 (151 coins)

summary: 10 radiates (Gallienus to Carausius) found along with fragments of a possible bronze container by a farm worker ploughing a field near Plas Nanteos. The coins entered the collection of a local antiquarian and were sold upon his death. No further information is available.
20 denarii, 11 studied: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) – Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Týniště nad Orlicí, inv.nos. 63–73, today missing.

summary: 4 antoniniani (Gordian III - Trajan Decius) found during field work.

1043 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 285-286). The emperors represented include: Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Divus Claudius II, 'Imp. Gallo', Aurelian and Probus. However, the original number of coins was ca. 3.840.
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Spain

summary: 10 Alexandria tetradrachms: Probus-Maximianus I (AD 284-285).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Regionale "P. Orsi", Siracusa: inv: 51795-51804

summary: In 1911 a container with Roman coins was found by Italian workers during excavation works for the Welzheim railway station. The precise find location could not be determined. The hoard was dispersed, but 277 coins reached the Stuttgart Museum, and 379 coins in a private collection were also documented. In total, 670 coins are listed in FMRD. Coins range from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander. They are mostly denarii, with a few antoniniani and 4 aurei.
disposition: Local museum, Welzheim, Germany; private collection

summary: The hoard comprised 10 Roman Imperial 'bronze' (i.e. antoniniani?) coins, found in a Roman bath house in the southern part of ancient Pella. The latest were of Aurelian, Florian and Probus.
The hoard comprised 105 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 bronze issues and was apparently deposited c. AD 263. No reasons are given for this date for deposition.
Over 1,500 coins were discovered at the Roman villa. Only 790 antoniniani (radiates) were studied: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
385 antoniniani (radiates found in a ceramic vessel: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 274); silver weight: 90.9-998.6 g.

The hoard was found in a copper-alloy vessel covered with a silver plate and comprised 73 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) vfrom Vespasian to Valerian I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 55.4g and 208.8g.

of 4,033 pieces, 3296 were recorded at the British Museum: 592 denarii, Domitian-Gordian III; 2704 antoniniani, Caracalla-Trajan Decius, including 2 “Divi”. The other were all antoniniani of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II and Trajan Decius.

The hoard comprised 'a lot of bronze and billon coins, of which 83 coins were recovered and give by M. Timbaud to the Musée de Rouen…'it is likely to represent a hoard or a portion of a hoard'; Antoninian dynasty - ; silver weight: 17.6-151.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Museum Inventory III, p. 61, no. 2157 (donated 17.5.1909)

summary: Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).

The hoard comprised between 960 and 1012 denarii from Galba to Elagabalus. Only 413 denarii from the hoard were studied. Silver: c.1000 coins; Silver weight: 1411.7-3148.3 g. Found under some stones by a farmer
disposition: Musees de Beaux-Arts, Quimper acquired 350 coins and Brest (Sociéte Academique) acquired 41.

summary: Roman coin hoard found in a pot during clay digging. 55 coins are preserved today with two further coins only known by their description, but the hoard might have comprised more coins. The coins range from Titus to Trajan Decius and were both bronze (48 sestertii and 1 dupondius) and silver (3 denarii and 5 antoniniani).
During the drainage of a moor several small Roman coins were unearthed. The names of six emperors are mentioned. Some coins seem to be plated.
17 sestertii and middle bronzes from Augustus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The coins listed here are those reported and declared Treasure at various inquests in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The findspot became public and coins were being regularly found at the site. Their findspot was no longer reported accurately and so the coins should probably be considered together (with caution) as a scattered hoard. It is possible that some of these coins are addenda to hoards 496 and 2634. These two hoards do appear to have been spatially separate, found above and below the Crags respectively, but it has been suggested that a hoard may have been disturbed and spilled over the Crags.
1089 silver coins: 14 denarii, 1076 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 259)
872 silver coins: 45 denarii, 10 denarii plated, 381 antoniniani, 434 antoniniani plated, 1 quinarius, 1 drachm: Commodus - Gallienus (AD 260-268)
1.616 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel which were deposit as a foundation offering beneath the theater orchestra: Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
A hoard of 52 bronze antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus) found in the quarry of Weisenau in 1910.

On the 30.5.1862, approximately 4,000 billon coins and small radiates dating to the third century AD were found during marshland reclamation work. On 21.07.1862, an excavation of the site, recovered a further 3,000 coins of the same date. The coins were deposited in two piles 1.5m from each other at a depth of 0.95m. They were found in a layer of aquatic plant debris. Fillon lists the emperors represented as Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II. There were no more than 100 coins dating to before the death of Postumus. According to Fillon, the radiates of Postumus without exception dated to the Ivth and Vth consulates. The coins of Tetricus made up 9/10ths of the hoard. There were about 10 coins of Aurelian (pre-reform) and for the most part were found in the second pile. Fillon's engravings indicate that there were also barbarous copies of coins of Divus Claudius, Victorinus and Tetricus. The hoard was found during drainage of marshland on the land of Mme de Craon-Beauveau.
395 silver coins: 280 antoniniani, 115 denarii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
704 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 683 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 10 asses: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254).

The hoard comprised a ceramic jar containing 37 bronze and silver coins dated between 146-139 BC and AD 193-211. The hoard was found in association with the remains of an ancient building, but this was destroyed during construction work.

Hoard of 225 coins: 1 imperial denarius, 8 gold stateri, 216 bronze staters of Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus Rhescuporis V, dated between AD 80 and AD 251.
106 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: The hoard comprised 12 Roman coins, of which 8 were identified by H. Desaye: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 7.5 g.
2,000 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Dispersend among locals, and buyers from Novara and Torino.

summary: 14 silver coins: Trajan – Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268). At the same place as ČESKA SKALICE 1884
disposition: Museum of Náchod, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 1605-1618)

summary: The hoard comprised a plain ceramic vessel containing 628 Roman coins from Trajan Decius to Tetricus I. These included 3 denarii of Postumus and 625 silver, billon or bronze coins (denarii and radiates) of several emperors. The coins of Claudius II and the Tetrici constituted 5/6ths of the hoard.

This hoard comprised 522 coins: 7 denarii, 515 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-263). Beside were discovered: 7 gold rings, 6 silver rings, 1 silvered bronze ring, 1 gold earring and 1 bronze earring.
Originally 164 coins, only 45 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 299).

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 334 coins were extracted from a hole sunk in the earth below two large stones, placed as it seemed, purposely above it. The coins were of Gallienus, Probus, Tacitus, and Claudius Gothicus.
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 1,500 antoniniani (radiates), including issues of Postumus.
The hoard comprised 20 silver coins from Julia Domna, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus and Salonina.
The hoard comprised 38 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Gallienus (sole reign).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 600 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius. A further sestertius of Marcus Aurelius was overstruck with a double sestertius of Postumus. The coins were arranged in textile bags. Fragments of the bags survived where coins touched the walls of the vessel.
727 denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no.8442-9165

summary: 163 antoniniani (radiates) found with a storage jar: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
11 provincial bronze coins minted in Deultum: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv. no. ?XXV

summary: Few hundreds denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Only 16 pieces recovered: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver weight: 28.8-66.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2146-2154

summary: The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised two vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 70 pieces are kept in the museum of Lovech: 12 denarii, 29 antoniniani, 29 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Lovech, department of Archaeology, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1675-1676

summary: Around 600 silver coins, of which 432 were seen: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

Hoard of 14 kilos of antoniniani (radiates) found during the construction of the overpass on the Corso Ivrea. 601 coins were transferred from the Regional Museum of Torino to the Soprintendenza della Valle d'Aosta: Trebonianus Gallus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
22 silver coins found in an ash layer at a Roman sacrificial place.
Unknown number of silver and provincial bronze coins. 100 silver coins were seen: Pertinax - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised 2,676 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Quietus, Postumus, Laelian, Victorinus, Marius, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius Gothicus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Probus, Diocletian and Maximian I.
1,606 silver coins: 604 denarii, 1,002 antoniniani of the 1st-3rd centuries AD.
The hoard comprised approximately 100 'small bronzes' - 'radiates' of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II The hoard was found in the Reverchon quarry
2043 AR: Galba/Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 2555.4-6392.7 g
The hoard comprised 1,104 radiates from Valerian and Gallienus to Quintillus. 740 have been studied by Salama. (AD 270)
The hoard comprised 12 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Salonina, Saloninus and Postumus.
1867 coins: 1650 antoniniani (radiates), 215 imitation antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius, 1 bronze: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 504.5-2330.3 g.
c. 100 antoniniani: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
The hoard comprised a small greyware vessel containing 50 silver and billon Roman coins ending in issues of Postumus. It was found not far from TAF VIII/2.1 (Oise) (CHRE 3546).
60 antoniniani of Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 75 g.

The hoard comprised 84 coins (probably radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Hostilian, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Valerian II.

In 1981 a hoard of 159 Antoniniani of the last third of the third century (Gallienus - Diocletian, and Gallic Empire) was unearthed during excavations of the Institute for Pre- and Early history of the University of Johannes Gutenberg at Mainz. The hoard was found in a cellar.

In 1864 reportedly more than 300 Roman coins were dug out at a field behind the Zorn'schen machine factory (on Landshuter street between Richard-Wagner street and Stobäusplatz). Descriptions of only 56 coins (1 denarius and 55 antoniniani, ranging from Julia Domna to Numerian) exist today. The coin of Numerian might not belong to this hoard.
The hoard comprised 91 denarii and 416 sestertii from Nero to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique départemental de Guiry-en-Vexin, France

summary: Hoard of initially 90 silver coins. 41 were recovered (denarii, antoniniani (radiates): Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
A hoard of 343 barbaric antoninianii (Gallienus - Carus, incl. Tetricus) and an unstruck flan were found in the substructure of a bathhouse of a villa rustica (HA 206).
Over 137 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 136 denarii, 1 drachm: Republic – Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (24 coins); Local Museum, Târpești (44 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a large quantity of coins, although only 11 were identified. They included issues of Gordian III, Gallienus and Salonina. It seems likely that this is the same hoard as one mentioned by M. Faujas de Saint-Fond in 1810 which comprised 'a very large number of medium and small bronze Roman coins from Gallienus to the House of Constantine'.
102 coins: 5 antoniniani, 23 sestertii, 74 bronze (sestertii?): Domitian - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 260-268); silver weight: 4.0-12.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique, Bruxelles, Belgium (102 coins)

summary: (300) 229 coins: 1 sestertius, 228 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 64.2-669.9 g.
175 antoniniani entered museum collection in Kardzhali: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
14 denarii (late Republic to Severus Alexander) were found in 1906 in front of the door sill of cellar 83 (in the Roman settlement).

In 1927 about 360 denarii and antoniniani (Caracalla - Postumus) were unearthed. The coins were strewn on the ground, on a place located on the floodplain of the river Rhine. There was also half of a longsword, remnants of scissors, 4 bronze rings and 50 tokens of glass and glass base.

The surviving part of a larger hoard includes 16 denari and 6 antoniniani (radiates) from Mark Antony to Philip I (32 BC-247 AD) kept in a private collection. The original amount of the hoard remains unknown. Given the very little distance between the two findspots, Masi I and Masi II should be two sections of the same hoard deposited in different places by its owner.
600 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Found close to the hoard ETTELBRÜCK 1889. Silver: 592 coins; Silver weight: 161.1-740.3g.
The deposit was discovered over the course of several seasons of excavation at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site and comprised 27 bronze coins of Postumus.

A small bronze cauldron containing a linen bag with the coins. The money consists of 889 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Two pieces of silver-plated crockery, a plate and a platter, were found next to the cauldron.
The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus with a tpq of AD 282.
52 coins: 1 denarius, 31 antoniniani (radiates), 5 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 2 unknown denomination: Vespasian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

More than 100 bronze coins have been found. 68 were seen: Commodus - Gordian III - minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum 35, Marcianopolis 27, Hadrianopolis 3, Anchialus 2, Serdica. 19 are kept in the museum collection in Lyaskovets.
Three aurei part of a chain, 2 mounted in pendants: Valerian I (2), Valerianus II Caesar) (AD 255-256)
51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.

The hoard comprised a jug containing an agglomeration of 1,454 Roman coins found with a small ceramic vessel. Gallia states that 1,458 coins were found, but only 1,454 were detailed. TAF suggests that a further 4 unidentified coins could be added: Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: c.248.3-1144.0g.
2,596 denarii (among: 1 plated, 47 'barbarous'): Republic - Caracalla (AD 214).
Over 2,000 aurei found with a ceramic vessel: Tiberius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); gold weight: c. 12801.4-15598.6g.

The hoard comprising a large earthenware vessel covered with a tile containing between 40 and 80kg of silver and billon coinage (denarii and radiates). A catalogue of 4084 coins was given to J. de Witte by the owner. A portion of the assemblage belonging to the finder was sold. ; Silver weight: 737.8-11636.9g.
Hoard found during ploughing, 200 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
809 silver coins: 91 denarii, 718 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) - Valerian I (AD 258). Found with two ceramic vessels.

6,263 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Rome (4,921); Viminiacum (4); Milan (340), Ticinum (6); Cologne (44); Trier (38); Lyon (2); Siscia (216); Sirmium (2); Antioch (2); Cyzicus (12); uncertain (4); imitations (1,068): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 287-289). Found during the laying of electrical cables.
47 coins - 1 antoninianus (radiate), 45 sestertii, 1 as - found with a ceramic vessel in a Roman villa: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).

The hoard comprised an urn containing 1,200 coins, mostly thought to be dupondii ('moyens bronzes'), but with some asses ('petits bronzes') and denarii. The coins range from issues of Vespasian to Severus Alexander.
32 coins: 23 sestertii, 7 dupondii and 2 antoniniani (radiates): Titus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
1,739 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0 g.
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), of which only 39 pieces were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing at least 313 antoniniani (radiates) radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; private collection

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vase containing 73 antoniniani (radiates) (or 60 according to Blanchet) from Gallienus to Probus.

The hoard was found in a large ceramic vessel. Within the vessel were five corroded blocks of coins, each coated with very hard clay. Two thirds of the hoard was cleaned (except for 2 blocks weighing 5.5kg) and it appears that there were approximately 1,500 coins (bronzes and radiates). Between 200 and 250 coins were of the emperors between Augustus and Gallienus. The others were of Aurelian, Probus and Diocletian. The hoard was found by a farm labourer.
2000 silver coins found during road repairing works: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Unknown number of denarii. 56 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Nero - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2590

summary: One aureus of Tacitus, one gold barbarous imitation of an aureus, 4 drachms Hadrian, 1 denarius Septimius Severus were found in a grave together with jewelry.
(169) 137 coins: 5 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 as: Domitian - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver weight: 10.0-16.2 g
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (137, maybe 169 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 9 aurei, some gold jewellery and a jet amulet. Gold: 9 coins; Gold weight: 45.4-46.0g. The entire hoard was acquired by Dr. E. Poncet for his private collection.
30 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani. 12 pieces were recovered: 5 antoniniani, 7 denarii: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 39.0-70.0 g.
1,126 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 Ptolemaic bronze coins: Ptolemaic dynasty - Aurelian (AD 270-275). 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly'.
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Ruse: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 1-43

summary: Unknown quantity of provincial bronze coins. 2 pieces of Caracalla minted in Serdica are known
154 silver coins: 149 denarii, 5 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-239); silver weight: 217.9-454.5 g.
Unknown original number of coins. Only 10 pieces were recovered: 8 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 plated denarius: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
The hoard comprises 1,931 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Philip I, as well as a single drachm of Geta from Caesarea in Cappadocia. Found with a ceramic vessel.
18 (?) silver coins, found 1925 on the street 'Am Römerwall'. 21 coins are mentioned in the inventory of the Altermusmuseum, but the coins are now lost.
170 provincial coins: Nicopolis ad Istrum 77, Marcianopolis 69, Hadrianopolis 6, Odessos 4, Anchialus 9, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
17 antoniniani (radiates) found while building a house: Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) - Probus (AD 276-282).
45 silver coins: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 63.1-128.9 g.
Hoard found in a ceramic vessel consisting of 80 denarii. One denarius of Severus Alexander is known.
(303) 292 silver coins: 240 denarii, 52 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 380.4-892.2 g.

Scattered hoard, found in the Dünnern river bed during correction works of the river bed. Over 1100 coins reported, 906 of them preserved. 8 coins from the 1st/2nd c. AD, the others range from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Postumus to Tetricus II. Mostly antoniniani, except for the 1st/2nd c. coins and a denarius of Gordian III. Large numbers of coins from Gallienus and Claudius II.

The 15 (lost) coins, "mostly poorly preserved middle bronzes from Augustus to Trebonianus Gallus", were found in 1913/14 during earthworks on the edge of a ravine near the Bühren estate. "The coins were scattered over 100 m, 1 m deep."
(40) 20 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: c.14.6-84.0 g.
disposition: Collection Derjicke, Iddergem, Belgium (20 coins), in 1965

summary: Few hundreds coins found with a large ceramic vessel and wonderful jewelry. 53 coins were studied: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 239-241); silver weight: 75.8-153.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Oltenia, Craiova, Romania (53 coins).

summary: The hoard was found in a small wooden box and comprised between 5 and 600 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

In 1898 42 coins (1 denarius and 41 antoniniani, Macrinus - Postumus) coins came into view during peat digging on the field 'Am Schachen' in the area of Spesbach. The coins were concealed together in a clump, 70-80 cm below the surface. The coins were lost during WWII.
61 coins found during fieldwalking and research at the place: 59 antoniniani, 2 denarii: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257).
Four radiates foundfused together.

14 bronze coins, ranging from Caracalla to Philip, found in a clay vessel in the destruction layer of a building in the north section of the Agora. More than 100 bronze (provincial, judging from those ill. in fig. 4 in AEMTh 18, 2004, p. 382) coins were also found in the same layer.
The hoard comprised Roman coins dating to the third century AD.
332 silver coins: 45 denarii, 287 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 383-758.6 g. Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum, vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M II 3011-3330 (320 coins)

summary: 8 denarii found stuck together within a necropolis: Elagabalus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised more than 230 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta and Julia Domna) - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 288.1-596.9 g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (198 coins; inv.nos. III 2099-2102); Musée d'Avranches (32 coins)

summary: 160 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: AM Zagreb (41); ZM Sarajevo (114); Fojnica monastery; dispersed

summary: in 1852 on a hoard was dug out on a hill in a peat deposit of the Landstuhl municipality, on the island called Krimm. 11 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani, Geta - Philip) were published, but it remains unclear if this is the entire find or not.

1,300 antoniniani (radiates). "Due to the poor state of preservation of the radiates hidden in Varzi, which were completely covered by corrosive elements… The first group of 95 radiates were restored between 2020 and 2021 […] The issuing authorities are Gallienus (3%), Claudius II (64%), Quintillus (8%) and Aurelianus (3%). The remaining part (22%) consists of unidentifiable specimens. Only 43 radiates can be attributed (for now) to a specific mint: the majority to the Siscia one (86%), followed by Rome (11%) and Mediolanum (3%)."
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologia Belle Arti e Paesaggio, Pavia, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 600 coins. However, only 268 coins were catalogued: . The rest were sold: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian /Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Instituto Arqueologia de la Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal (200 coins); Mário de Castro Hipólito collection (68 coins)

summary: Hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 30 coins were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293)
65 billon Alexandrian tetradrahms: Nero - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 292-293). 'Presented to the owner by Felix Cary in Marseilles and reported to have been found in Upper Egypt in 1760.'
disposition: 'Probably now in Gotha as the rest of Schachmann's collection'

summary: 11 bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241-244).
27 denarii: Vespasian for Titus (Caesar) - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: scattered in post pole - interpreted as save hoard, not ritual construction votive

summary: 462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
101 coins: 16 denarii, 85 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight 122.1-240.8 g.
disposition: Regional Historical Museum, Vidin, Bulgaria; inv.no. 591

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 72 antoniniani (radiates) were available for study: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
On the site of the Roman theatre, a hoard of 24 sestertii wrapped in cloth was found .
54 silver coins: 26 antoniniani, 28 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 72.6-130.1 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CCXX

summary: 1,548 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 204); silver weight: 2,788.4-4,765.7 g.
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii from Titus to Gordian III.
The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.
Hoard of circa 60 antoniniani (radiates) with coins from Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
600 antoniniani (radiates), of which 122 were recovered: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293); silver weight: 22.3-146.6 g.
The hoard comprised a red ceramic vessel containing 4,066 radiates of Postumus, Macrianus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian and Tacitus.
Originally were 420 silver coins. 274 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 273 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 259-268).
disposition: Town Museum Koprivnica, Croatia (274 coins); partly dispersed - 1982

summary: 230 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of small radiates (officials or imitations?), from Victorinus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
25 silver coins, 5 recovered: Septimius Severus Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 7.1-9.3 g.
370 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Marius (AD 269); silver weight: 102.2-959.7 g.

Six denarii "fairly close together, possibly a small purse hoard. Not possible to obtain details of 2 of these, but the remaining 4 consists of: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
100 sestertii found together on an opus signinum floor: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) (AD 251-253).
1,325 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Philip I - Probus (AD 276-282).
A hoard of 1,016 of coins was found with an amphora. The majority of coins were bronze issues of the Bosporus kingdom. A billon antoninianus (radiate) of Gordian III was found among the coins.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Simferopol

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Popovo and Targovishte: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Popovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 306 (92 coins); History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 689 (13 coins)

summary: 1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
254 radiate imitations and a single radiate found as a dispersed hoard over 4x1.5m area, within depth of up to 0.20m of soil. No sign of a container. No further contextual details.
1243 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius from Caracalla to Valerian I.

A hoard of 381 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani ranging from Geta to Postumus) and 1 provincial coin, found in a vessel surrounded by fire rubble in a building located in front of the SE corner of the Roman fort. The coins had been contained in a bag made of hemp. A large number of ornaments had been placed on top to the vessel.
244 silver coins: 117 denarii, 127 antoniniani: Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found in a bronze vessel.
Unknown number of Roman provincial bronze coins were found in unknown circumstances. 38 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22168-22205

summary: 167 silver coins: 97 denarii, 70 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Diocletian (AD 295).
disposition: formerly Regional museum Tiel (destroyed during WWII)

summary: Around 25 kg = 7,656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
1,486 tetradrahms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) in a disintegrated cloth bag on the floor of underground room J during excavations of a house.
(1000-1200) 113 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tetrarchy (AD 293-294); silver weight: 217.1-1,499.1 g.
19 antoniniani found during archaeological excavations: Aurelian, Tacitus, Probus
Unknown number of denarii and antoniniani. 30 pieces were seen by V. Haralanov: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

In 1837, 143 denarii and antoniniani were found on a field (Mühlen) next to the lime kiln, during excavation of an old boundary stone. No trace of a container was seen. Of these 143 coins, only 32 (Tiberius - Severus Alexander) have been described.
(2000) 167 silver coins: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 39.3-79.5 g.

On the site of a Roman temple or shrine (?) in a field: 30 coins, significantly limited to the inner recessed area. The number joined by corrosion suggests the possibility of a disturbed hoard. They are mainly debased antoniniani covering the same period as the hoard found during the last century. Undated. Late 3rd century AD
146 coins: 1 denarius, 91 antoniniani (radiates), 49 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 3 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Marcus Aurelius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
349 denarii: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228)
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 9

summary: A hoard of 7 antoniniani (Gallienus and Claudius II), found in a destruction layer of Monument H in the Sanctuary of Poseidon and Amphitrite.
