The hoard was found in an earthen pot in the forest. It comprised 33 denarii from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-236). Only 29 are now recorded.
1,937 antoniniani (radiates) found in a cooking pot: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 263).
1310 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-259) coins; silver weight: 1496-3124.7 g.
137 silver coins: 112 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Clodius Albinus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 176.8-335.2 g.
Unknown original number of coins. Thre is some scarce information on 23 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
A large hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 204 coins were noticed: Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284); silver weight: 36.8-65.2 g.
55 silver coins, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, found during construction work.
In 1959, D. Kienast may have investigated the listed series of coins in art-dealing, which reportedly were picked up as a hoard find in the city area.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 275 sestertii and dupondii or asses, arranged in piles from Domitian to Gordian III. Two thirds of the hoard were unidentifable because of a thick layer of corrosion products. The hoard was found in a wood on the Tesnières wood in the roots of an oak tree. Fragments of the ceramic vessel and part of the hoard were acquired by the Musée du Mans
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 260 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 2449-251)
269 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel during metal detecting: 252 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 13 asses: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
The hoard comprised coins from Gallienus to Probus. There are some doubts on the real number of coins from this hoard!
The hoard comprised 34 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus; Silver weight: 33.8g.
27 sestertii found together in a room from a Roman building considered to shave served as a warehouse.
Few hundred coins. Only 98 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) are recovered: Elagabalus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).
Silver: 1000+ (83) antoniniani/radiates: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 271.0-1249.0 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (978 coins); dispersed

summary: It comprised c. 150 sestertii. 145 had been studied from Trajan to Gordian III.

The hoard was found in a wooden box measuring 30cm by 30cm which was hidden in a cavity under a large stone. It comprised 6 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip, Gallienus and Divus Valerian II (AD 253-260).
1,764 coins, probably antoniniani (radiates), found with two ceramic vessels: Valerian I - Diocletian and Maximian I (AD 284-293).
(1500) 1140 silver coins: 463 denarii, 677 antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: 1639.0-3601.0 g.

In 1953 a hoard was salvaged between Jahn and Gerhart-Hauptmannstraße. Only part of the hoard could be saved. Coins include 87 denarii, sestertius and dupondii, ranging from Nero (?) to Severus Alexander.
1,401 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
21 antoniniani. T. Gerasimov saw 2 of Gordian III
5,056 silver coins found in one or more ceramic vessels: 17 denarii, 5,039 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 966.5g.

The hoard is composed of 10 poorly preserved Antonine bronzes. It was found during three archaeological(?) surveys of Noires-Terres in the Bois-en-Ardres in February 1980, at the end of 1981 and in early 1982) and interpreted as the remains of a dispersed hoard, as they were all found in the same place.
(250) 121 denarii found within an ancient settlement: Republic - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
A big vessel full of Roman imperial coins, bronzes and antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Hoard of 1,500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found in several amphoras: Clodius Albinus - Gallienus (AD 260-268). Found together with a gold chain.
A hoard of 89 denarii (Vespasian to Septimius Severus, AD 201) found during the second excavations conducted by A.H. Layard at Kouyunjik, one of the two mounds within the ancient walls of Nineveh.
44 silver coins: 16 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 243-244); Silver weight: 57.8-100.7g
(30) 7 silver and bronze coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoniniani; 1 provincial bronze; 3 bronze unid. denom: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Private collection Andrei Pănoiu - architect, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 494 coins found with a bronze vessel: 2 gold medallions, 6 aurei, 486 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 63.6 g.; silver weight: 133.8-1515.2 g. The hoard was found by a farmer. The multiple of Gallienus was acquired by the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.

The only information given about this hoard is that it 'begins with an issue of Domitian, there are a few issues of 2nd-century emperors with the majority of coins dating the first half of the third century AD.
Ca. 100 antoniniani (Gallienus to Tetricus II) found in a pot behind the wall of a Roman house, close to the Schloßplatz. 65 have been described in FMRD, the others are lost.
6 Roman provincial bronze coins were found in an ancient wall: Commodus and Caracalla. Mints of Serdica and Hadrianopolis.

The hoard was found within the temple temenos in Insula 20 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 390 denarii and radiates from Marcus Aurelius to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269, as well as a gold finger ring, two silver finger rings, a pair of gold earrings, a silver bowl, three silver spoons, some silver fragments and a copper-alloy vessel. A silver denarius of Hadrian was set into one of the silver finger rings.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 400 Roman sestertii from Nerva or Trajan to Postumus. 77 coins were examined.

'The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel filled with approximately 40 gold, silver and bronze coins with portraits of Trajan, Claudius II and Probus. The composition of this hoard is thought to be suspect.' The hoard was found in a small valley on the Guillet property.
HER record of an unrecorded late third-century hoard found by a metal-detectorist along with pottery sherds, a bracelet and a finger ring "with opposed dolphins".

The hoard comprised two separate deposits. The first contained 28 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Postumus. The second contained 622 radiates from Philip I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270. The circumstances of discovery means that a clear relationship between the two hoards cannot be established with any certainty.
54 from the 600 coins are known. All are antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: c.162g.
203 silver coins, 5 denarii, 198 antoniniani (radiates), found in earthenware with two golden jewels: Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised around 16,000 antoniniani, found around 1963. Nothing further is known about it.
17 antoniniani (radiates) found in the wall plaster of a domestic building: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 5.6-20.3g.
933 denarii and 2 antoniniani (radiates) spanning from Mark Antony to Maximinus I (AD 235-238).

(c. 180) 31 antoniniani (radiates). Although are mention imperial portraits from Pupienus to Gallienus and Salonina the only more accurate Information on 31 coins is for issuers from Gordian III to Valerian I. The tpq hypothetically can be placed on AD 268; silver weight: 225.0 g.
disposition: Musée Château d'Annec, France (partially); Inv.no. 5352; registre d'entrées, I, p. 184, no. 5352

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. 29 coins entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised a metal vessel containing 43 Roman coins, including 4 bronzes and 39 denarii and radiates from Trajan to Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole)(Gallienus) (AD 253-268). The hoard, missing 10 coins, is in the collections of the Musée de Rouen. The silver mirror and vessel are lost. In the Hoard file in the Archives of the Musée des Antiquités is a handwritten note without a date (April 1912) listing 38 coins.
50 silver coins. 15 pieces were seen: 5 antoniniani, 10 denarii; silver weight: 65.2-131.5 g.
444 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Together were found two silver spoons
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alerxander (AD 222-235). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis
The hoard was found in an amphora and comprised 63 coins of Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
350 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only coin of Julia Maesa is known.
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1,065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1,053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.

Chappée and the Vicomte d'Elbenne bought two lots of coins (approximately 2,000) which were sold as part of a hoard weighing 20kg. They were found in a ceramic urn in a field next to the station in Sillé-le-Guillaume or in Rouessé-Vassé or in Mayenne (Voutré or Sainte-Suzanne). The Musée du Mans has preserved a manuscript note related to a lot of 583 coins weighing 1,453g and quantifying these coins by emperor: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
3,000 coins: Septimius Severus – Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.

summary: The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 600 coins, apparently antoniniani (radiates). A further 9 coins were recovered from the bed of a small stream that ran into the pond. These coins were of the same emperors as those contained in the hoard.

Several thousand Roman coins reported to have been found in 1852. 32 coins, findspot mentioned "Malvaglia" and "Val di Blenio", entered the collection of the Antiquarische Gesellschaft Zürich (AGZ) and have now integrated the collections of the Schweizerisches Nationalmuseum, Zürich. They are probably part of this hoard (32 antoniniani, Aurelian to Diocletian).
disposition: Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (32 coins); the other ones are lost.

summary: The hoard was found hidden in the hollow base of a statue and comprised coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Probus and Tacitus. The nummus of Constantine I/Gratian, probably, a intruder.
An Antoninianus of Gordian III, discovered along with 10 other similar coins in 1909 during the construction of the Baumgartenbridge over the Havel-Schielow lake.
The hoard was found in a funerary urn and apparently comprised 50 'small bronzes' or radiates of Gallienus.
The hoard was found in pot with 1,600 low-grade silver coins of Postumus. Silver: c.1600 (500) coins; Silver weight: c.432
Three coins of Postumus were found in the basement area of the hypocaust heating room inside the main building of a villa rustica located north-east of Niederzier, in the 'München Busch' wooded area.
c. 400 of antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Town museum, Oudenaarde, Belgium (some coins and the vessel); collection C.A. Serrure, in 1861

summary: The hoard comprised 75 tetradrachms (Nero-Trebonianus Gallus), found in the vicinity of Jerusalem.

summary: The hoard comprised 'a block of between 200 and 400 radiates.': Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269.
1700 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
38 imitation antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I found under the granite foundations of a central building from the fort.
320 denarii and antoniniani found in a building from the ancient settlement. 22 coins were reviewed: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A hoard of 25 aurei (Faustina I - Trajan Decius), one medallion of Gallienus and 16 articles of jewellery, found at Octavian Augustus Street in the ancient Jewish quarter in Alexandria.
Unknown initial umber of coins. 46 denarii: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 222).

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Galerius (Caesar) with a tpq of AD 293 to 294. It was found during the excavation of the Roman amphitheatre.

520 imperial and provincial bronze coins: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249). The bulk of the coins consists in issues of Marcianopolis (249+ ex.), followed by coins from Odessus, Tomis, Anchialus, Mesembria, Dionysopolis and Bizya.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (450 coins)

summary: On the eastern exterior of the late Roman NO-tower of the cathedral in Trier, a shaft for the protection of the tower foundation was laid out during maintenance work in 1980. The hoard was dug out in a depth of 5.20m. The 43 coins were soldered together in spherically formed clumps. The coins were originally preserved in a leather bag and lay on an antique stone floor.
A hoard of 276 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in room 2 of B. 8, east of the Agora.
237 silver denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 297.8-690.4 g.

summary: Hoard of circa 100 coins. Only two pieces are known: Claudius I sestertius, Caracalla provincial bronze minted in Serdica.
1,049 bronze coins found in three ceramic vessels placed one next to the other: 1,045 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 1 as: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).

summary: The hoard comprised a glass bottle containining more than 146 denarii from Nero to Elagabalus. The glass bottle, which acted as the container for the hoard, is preserved by the Musée de Mans (Inv. V. 62)
Small group of denarii and radiates and a finger ring found together, possible purse hoard.
1,100 or 1,000 coins found with a bronze vessel. and gold coins from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
1,898 coins: 2 denarii, 1,895 antoniniani (radiates), 1 nummus: Valerian I - Tetrarchy I (AD 296-297).

summary: 315 denarii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2319/1-315

summary: Ten antoniniani of which one of Tacitus.

Two radiate minimi (8 and 7 mm, 0.40 and 0.34 g., one with head to left, and one from dies too big for the flan), found with 'about seven others' and a coin of Victorinus (Elmer 743, slightly worn) were discovered on the 13th tee of Pyle and Kenfig golf-course, before 1955. There were also some fragments of pottery.

summary: 1,088 denarii and antoniniani were found in a copper vessel: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 300 'small bronze' Roman coins, probably radiates. Only one coin was described, a radiate of Probus with a MARS VICTOR reverse.

summary: The hoard comprised two aurei of Commodus, some silver denarii and an unknown number of bronze denominations. A further three solidi, including one of Constantine I and one of Constans, as well as a poorly described issue were also found although it is to be doubted whether they formed part of the hoard.
1007 silver coins: 201 denarii, 806 antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together with a silver brooch.

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing an unknown number of third century Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products. They were found on the site of an Iron Age oppidum. 141 coins: Septimius Severus - Quintillus (AD 270)
2 aurei of Carausius, found in spoil after the construction of a building near Ashbourne.
Unknown originally number of coins. 49 denarii recovered: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 223); silver weight: 70.2-143.0 g.
216 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 215 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 242-244); silver weight: 303.1-491.4 g.
40 asses and sestertii. 18 coins entered the collection Gerville: 1 Antoninus Pius, 1 Marcus Aurelius, 16 Postumus.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 27 coins entered museum collection in Haskovo: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. N 656, N 1039

summary: Found during construction work. The subsequent excavations provided no information on any archaeological context. The findspot is situated in the slope above the vicus of Muralto. Hoard/deposition of 4869 aes coins: 1 as, 1 dupondius and 4867 sestertii, in an amphora, Claudius I to Gallienus (253/254).

The total number of coins originally found is unknown. There are two catalogues which slightly vary in the numbers of coins present. The one in May 1968 is entered here: Claudius II (Divus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Hoard 2 from Housesteads. Brickstock and Casey in Rushworth ed. 2009, 375 describe the hoard thus: "consists of four Radiate Copies found corroded together (SF No. 9396) in 1981 in H14:4:7, the chalet barrack phase of Building XIV. The identifiable prototypes of the copies are issues of Tetricus I and II (AD 270-73). Deposition may have taken place early in the period AD 273-86 (Period 19) since the copies are of large module and relatively unworn."

14 aureii (13 mounted): Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 204); gold weight 110 g. Found with a bronze pitcher. The content: two crosses; three chains; a brooch; sixty-eight pendants and sixty-four grains of necklace; fourteen coins of Roman emperors of the second-third century, the Antonines mainly, and two bracteates.

The hoard comprised a gold necklace and 20 copper-alloy coins from Commodus and Caracalla. The archive report questions whether this deposit represents a horad but does not provide any further explanation.
The hoard comprised about 200 silver coins from Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius to Gallienus.
The hoard comprised 71 silver coins and 85 bronze coins from a Roman shipwreck.
Around 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) found with amphoras on a shipwreck. 229 coins were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293).

summary: 116 coins found in 1870 close to Moneybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed two separate hoards (one consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).

Single finds of 21 Roman coins, Tiberius to Gallienus, found during metal detectorists' surveys on the site of a Roman villa rustica. Some of these might be part of a scattered hoard. Among coins found 1998-2011: 11 antoniniani and 10 denarii, Antoninus Pius to Gallienus (joint reign) and Postumus. 9 of these have been published with full references.

At least three aes coins (Domitian and Gallienus), along with numerous other finds, including a tombstone, mortarium, glassware, fibulae, and studs, discovered while digging the foundations of the new gaol (now HMP Usk) on the field known as 'Cae Puta'. The two radiates of Gallienus might constitute a hoard, but the addition of the single aes of Domitian throws this into doubt. In lieu of more accurate information concerning their context, it is just as likely that all three are single finds instead of a hoard. Nash-Williams (1928) speculated that the site might have been the location of a fort.
The hoard comprises 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I with a tpq of AD 274.

21 bronze coins,found with two pebbles and a bronze ring in the fill of the outer fort ditch. Found concreted together and later separated, probably a purse hoard although no traces of a container survived.

Of the c. 22,500 coins found, 4513 are identifiable to RIC number. Only part of these coins are preserved today.

822 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Marcus Aurelius - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 294-295). Finding spots according to the Arad dealers from whom Milne bought the hoards in Cairo. The two hoards had almost the same composition, got mixed together on the way back to England, therefore have been listed as a single find.

575 denarii: Nero – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Unknown number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 44 pieces enetered the museum collection in Popovo: Traian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

This find can only be traced on paper, as it is only available as a manuscript by Christian Friedrich Hoffmann. It is stated that Hoffmann led excavations in the fort in the years 1791, 1800, 1804 and 1813-1815. His extensive manuscript was found in the Princely Wied archive in Neuwied in 1811. In 1991 the content was revised in Frankfurt am Main. Hoffmann describes 256 coins that are said to have been found “in a yellow metal chalice”. Thanks to Hoffmann's detailed description, almost all coins could be assigned. These are 213 denarii and 43 antoniniani (radiate). Most date from the reigns of Septimius Severus, Elagabalus, and Severus Alexander. The final coin, minted in AD 259.
Unknown number of silver coins. 33 antoniniani seen by T. Gerasimov: Gordian III - Trajan Decius.
64 antoniniani (radiates) found near a kiln within the south-west district of the Roman city: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
745 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 293).
1258 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 1623.4-3383.4 g.
Possible hoard of 7 silver coins and 27 bronze coins. Late Republic - Philippus I (AD 247).
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. For only two coins are known the issuers: Domitian and Septimius Severus. The archives mention that the coins were minted between years 81 and 222.
(c. 1000) 88 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 1251.6-2848.4 g
Unknown initial number of coins. 2788 antoniniani: Philip I - Gallienus (AD 260-268)

summary: 381 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised 2,769 coins including a plated copy of a denarius of Severus Alexander and radiates from Valerian to Probus. It was found concealed in a broken ceramic vessel covered with a schist slab in a cavity in the southern wall of Building E (V) of a Gallo-Roman villa. Elements of the hoard were found on two occasions. First, in August 1983 and then in 1984 when further excavation of the site took place. Severus Alexander (plated denarius); Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1984-72

summary: An upturned bowl made of white metal under which coins lay. Some of the coins were bound together into one chunk by oxidation. 192 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 257). Together gold jewelry was found: two pinheads connected by a chain, a pendant decorated with base emeralds and an onyx cameo. Apparently, the jewelry had been in a now rotted wooden box. This assumption is supported by fittings found near the jewelry and a broken bronze key. The circumstances of discovery indicate that the casket was not originally buried.
The hoard was found in two vessels by workers. For the city master, it comprised c. 8,000 antoniniani (radiates). Among these coins, 796 from Valerian to Diocletian were identified.
The hoard comprised 180 tetradrachms (Nero-Macrinus), 22 denarii (Septimius Severus-Geta), and 35 bronze coins (Alexander Severus-Philip I). Details for 145 of the coins have been published.

in 1917, the museum received a small bronze container without lid that was said to have contained 18 coins (antoniniani, Gallienus to Tetricus), and probably found in Mainz-Kastel. The coins are lost.
44 coins found in a grave in Lefkohori, Langada in 1970. The coins included one denarius (Marcus Aurelius) and 43 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa, Dium, Pella, Stobi, koinon of Macedonia).

During a violent storm in 1991, coins and many other artefacts dating from the Roman Empire, such as pottery vessels and bronze weights, were washed up from the seabed a short distance from the ancient city of Camarina on the most south-easterly point of Sicily. Among issuers: Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Camarina, Italy

summary: Hoard of over 100 silver coins, 94 are known: 93 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 229). Found together with jewelry: 4 silver bracelets, 5 silver finger rings, 1 bronze finger ring; silver weight: 134.1-276.7g.
33 coins: 1 denarius, 32 antoniniani (radiate) found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma': Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
(?) 17 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Julia Domna, Gordian III, Valerian I, Gallienus, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
15 probably antoniniani (radiates). According to NUMIS they are dated around AD 270. No further information.
It comprised 258 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
During the digging of a ditch three asses were found placed in a small amphora which was placed in a bigger one: Sextus Pompeius as, Augustus as, Philip I as,
261 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

summary: Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 sestertii from Trajan to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). 92 were acquired by the City Museum of Nevers.
Three bronze coins: 2 sestertii of Hadrian, 1 double sestertius of Postumus (AD 264-265) found in a layer of ashes in a cellar of a Roman building.
300 silver and billon coins: 1 Augustus, 1 Vespasian, ending with Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 8,864 antoniniani (radiates) Valerian I - Carinus (tpq AD 283, Numerian). Silver weight: 1596.1-6470.3 g.
It comprised c. 400 silver coins. Only 149 are now recorded: 148 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimus Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole).
Four burned antoniniani (radiates). Only one coin, antoninianus (radiate) of Gordian III (AD 241-243) was identified.

The hoard was found in a tomb and comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 75 (or 78) radiates, 17 surgical implements and 5 tinned or silvered containers, which probably originally contained ointment: Victorinus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
186 coins: 185 antoniniani (radiates), 1 billon Alexandrian drachm: Gallienus - Maximian I. Circumstances of find not known.
118 coins : 114 bronzes and 4 denarii (1 nummus of Constantin intrusive)
22 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic jug in a room of the Roman villa: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
212 coins were preserved. They comprise radiates, Reform radiates of Aurelian and 3 denarii of Severina
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: The context of the treasure burying, although partly known, remains problematic : in fact, there are two deposits of precious objects, very close to each other but quite distinct, inside caches which were laid under the ground. Should they be attributed to the occupants of the houses from the second half of the 3rd century AD, or to the occupants of the potter's workshop following in the beginning of the 4th century AD? The first deposit gathers together two silver bracelets and a group of statuettes in the same metal, more or less fragmentary. Three of them are fully preserved : one Helios dedicated to an emperor's numen, one Fortuna with a double horn of plenty and one goddess, more enigmatic, carrying a dish with two birds inside. The head of a Jupiter and of an amazing personage with two outgrowths as an ornament in the hair add to the whole which is completed by a bust-portrait, probably representing an emperor (Gallienus?). The second deposit, locked inside a wooden box, consists of crookery, jewels and coins. The silverware is made up of one dish decorated with a Mercure, two small trays ornated with reliefs (one of them just in bronze and silver plated), fourteen spoons and two fragmentary cutleries. All these objects belong to well known series in Gaul : their shapes and decoration show that they were made in the 3rd century AD. The set of jewels includes two golden bracelets, two pairs of golden, emerald, pearl and molten glass pendant earrings, two bezel rings (one of them with a nicolo), and one coin medallion (Gordian III aureus, AD 238-244). At the bottom of the box, there was a purse with 81 well preserved silver coins - 29 denarii and 52 antoniniani (radiates) - with a chronological curve stretching from Vitellius (AD 69) to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallian (AD 253-260). In fact, there are two different sets : one with 62 coins, that is to say 19 "old" denarii from Vitellius to Commodus, eight more recent all dated AD 201, 33 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius struck between AD 215 and AD 217 for Caracalla, as well as, one denarius of Diadumenian in AD 218; the second set comprises 19 antoniniani (radiates) coins issued between AD 241 and AD 258. One can wonder about the precise nature of these deposits. The sculptures found there do not have quite a homogeneous construction ; maybe a kind of Lares altar or objects belonging to a sanctuary, as most of them represent divinities, and one at least, the birds’ goddess, seems to have a strong local connotation. The silverware hardly represents more than two pounds of metal ; it is therefore difficult to speak of a "table set" all the less as the spoons are rather incomplete. The set of jewels, which is more coherent and of good quality but with no exceptional piece, illustrates well the favourite jewels in the well-off classes of Gaul around the middle of the 3rd century AD. Regarding the coins, there are several arguments speaking for a saving, rather than for a reserve currency, which was formerly made (maybe following two main payments (donativa) in AD 202 and AD 217/218, and poorly completed by a contribution in antoniniani (radiates) around AD 258-260), a small family inheritance safeguarded for sentimental reasons, maybe one generation away. (Aubin, G. et al. 1999)
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 3,814 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 601.7-5745.9 g.
Circa 95 antoniniani (radiates). Dembski 1977 gives the evidence for 89: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 26.6-117.8g.

Hoard of 460 coins: 446 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Gallienus, 11 denarii from Caracalla to Gordian III and 3 Provincial bronzes (Septimius Severus of Hadrianoi and Gordian III of Metropolis).
disposition: National Museum, Athens, Greece (124 coins and the list of the entire hoard)

summary: Hoard of 281 antoniniani (radiates) found on the territory of the legionary fort: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns

summary: The hoard comprised a coarseware urn containing 1,806 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Allectus.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 47 coins were documented: Vespasian - Elagabalus (Julia Soaemias) (AD 218-222).
96 denarii found with a ceramic pitcher: Republic – Septimius Severus (AD 201-210).
disposition: History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (91 coins); Cultural room, Ardeoani (4 coins); High-school ”Vasile Alecsandri”, Bacău (1 coin)

summary: The hoard comprised 7.5 kg of antoniniani (radiates)of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus and Probus. 2,000 coins are identified.
A depot of 8 antoniniani and 1 denarius (Septimius Severus - Claudius II) found in a pit on one of the rooms of the villa rustica at Oensingen

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 114 coins lying in a kind of trench, below the bottom of the opening near the stoves, ranging from Gallienus to Carausius.
(c. 7 kg) 300 silver coins: Hadrian - Maximian I (A284-293); silver weight: 56.7-852.5 g.

A hoard of 907 coins, found in a broken clay pot during building work carried out with a bulldozer: one Parthian drachm (Orodes I), 771 didrachms and 4 drachms of Caesarea in Cappadocia up to Geta, and 131 Roman denarii up to Alexander Severus, as well as one drachm of Caracalla attributed to Petra and dated to AD 211-12 (listed as a coin of Elagabalus from Caesarea by Dundua 2008).
45 silver coins: 3 denarii, 42 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver weight: 57.1-113.3 g
16 antoniniani (radiates) found together buried in an unpafved floor of one of the rooms of the Roman villa: Gallienus (sole) - Divus Claudius II (AD 270).
disposition: Laboratório de Conservação e Restauro (Direcção Regional da Cultura do Alentejo), Portugal

summary: Seven imitations of silver denominations; silver weight: 151.4-695.3 g.

The coins were found in a stone sarcophagus along with some ashes. They comprised coins dating from the reign of Augustus (Altar of Lyon) to the reign of Maximinus (of Thrace?). The coins were found during the demolition of a tumulus.
The hoard was found inside a textile bag placed within a ceramic vessel and comprised approximately 300 silver coins, apparently all antoniniani (radiates). The hoard has a tpq of AD 261.
Hoard of 80 coins of Bosporan kings (AD 232-254). One denarius of Severus Alexander among the coins.
An unknown quantity of coins was found in the outskirts of an ancient settlement. 31 silver coins were examined: 13 antoniniani, 18 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2579

summary: The hoard comprised numerous fragments of silvered copper-alloy tableware accompanied by 21 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 244-249). TAF interprets it as a deposit of scrap metal intending for recycling.

A grave found in the peribolos of the west cemetery of ancient Rhodes (reused in late Roman times) contained a hoard comprising 4 Roman bronze coins: 1 of Aemilianus (in the mouth of the deceased), 1 of the first to second century AD, 1 of Caracalla and 1 of Alexander Severus (beside the head).
357 silver coins: 154 denarii, 203 antoniniani: Hadrian - Philip (AD 244-247); silver weight: 470.8-965.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria

summary: The hoard comprised a large earthenware vessel containing 1,100 bronze coins (for the most part sestertii) and 30 'small coins with surface silvering' (radiates). A summary catalogue of 200 of the best preserved examples was made by F. Homo. The hoard was found by workmen from the Letellier company during quarrying for stone. It was found at only a slight depth 'faible profondeur'.
Hoard of 1,000 silver coins: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). 8 coins are documented.
The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel with a lid containing between 1,800 and 2,000 radiates. No further information about the composition of the hoard was given.
Two ceramic vessels with around 500 coins: Elagabalus (Aquilia Severa) to Carinus (AD 283-285). Hobbs estimates the weight of 63.5-843.8g.
128 silver coins (antoniniani?): Balbinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Hoard of over 5,000 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
(circa 80) 26 silver coins: 3 denarii, 23 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania;

summary: Unknown number of denarii. 199 entered the museum collection in Silistra: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 217).

The hoard comprised about 50 kg antoniniani (radiates) of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Divo Claudio, Quintillus, Aurelian and Tacitus. 2,226 coins and one blank have been studied.
The workers discovered a metallic vase with 20 kg of coins (maybe antoniniani). Only 214 are now recorded, from Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland (part of the hoard)

summary: 151 silver coins: 17 denarii, 134 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Trebonianus Gallus/Volusianus (AD 253).
disposition: The Iron Gates Region Museum Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (1957)

summary: The hoard comprised 'a lot of 62 double sestertii of Postumus (AD 260-268). They were sold to a dealer in Rouen who claimed they had been found in Eu.

A Roman hoard was found and dispersed, in recent years in Nembro. Some bronze coins of the 3rd century were seen. It is an Antoninianus (radiate) from Salamina (sic!) and dupondii of Claudius II and Aurelian (determination of E. Arslan). Soprintendenza Archeologica della Lombardia (7 coins).
357 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 97.4-445.3 g.
disposition: Collezioni Governative del Medagliere Milanese, Italy (in 1923).

summary: 100-200 silver coins. Only 4 coins are known: 1 denarius, 3 antoniniani: Septimius Severus (Caracalla) - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

306 coins: 255 antoniniani (radiates), 50 denarii, 1 sestertius: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together, were found jewelry: 2 silver rings, 1 pair of gold earrings and 1 gold children’s earring.

A hoard of ca. 677 provincial coins, ranging from Commodus Caesar to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253-60), found in the sanctuary of Apollo Smintheion. Coins were mainly minted in Alexandria Troas (665 coins), but also in Parium (6 coins) and Abydus (1 coin). Çizmeli connects the deposition of this hoard with the invasions of the Goths in Asia Minor.
disposition: Laboratoire du Musée des Civilisations Anatoliennes, Ankara, Turkey

summary: The hoard comprised c. 700 coins including 200 sestertii and 500 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Claudius II.
During archaeological excavations, 11 burned bronze coins were found on the south-east corner of the basilica: 1 Rome, 10 provincial: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 238-244)

On the jaws of a skeleton near the previous one were seven well-preserved coins: one silver by Caracalla; another pure silver by Alessandro Severo; three of Aureliano and one of Caro, covered with silver, and one of copper belonging to Probus.

c. 1300 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-261). 'Common terracotta vase buried in a fairly deep hole, dug out in the sandstone. Found during excavations for a monumental tomb in the Armenian cemetery.'

IARCH record for scattered hoard of radiates (for full details see DOR-5D3543). Another hoard was previously found on the same field in 2013 (2013 T221 'Holt') with an addenda found in 2014 (2014 T962).
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 277 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus' joint reign with a tpq of 258 to 259.
Unknown number of silver coins. 236 are in the Museum collection in Ruse: 230 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Republic - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria;inv. no. 1661

summary: Unpublished hoard of three denarii in BM file report. Declared Treasure Trove in 1980.
1 denarius and 350 antoniniani (radiates) found in the neighborhood (ca. 100m) of another hoard (99 antoniniani): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing between 600 and 700 radiates of Gordian III to Postumus. The hoard was immediately dispersed, although subsequently two lots of coins were recovered for study.
150 coins: 140 sestertii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus/Gallienus (AD 251-268). A silver patera and a lead weight were discovered together with these coins.
1,071 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1065 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 267); silver weight: 290.7-2781.5g
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology Tulcea, Romania (1971)

summary: 1,000 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms 'Acquired by Dattari, who sold it to Milne.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 31 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M VI 9663-9693 (31 coins)

summary: 2 coins: 1 bronze Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/ Diva Faustina II), 1 antoninianus (radiate) Claudius II (AD 268-270)
The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.
Unknown initial number of antoniniani. 8 pieces entered the museum collection in Sofia: Gordian III 1, Philip I 1, Otacilia Severa 1, Trajan Decius 5.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21422-21429 (8 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 583 radiates from Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 175.8g to 727.8g.

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
7 coins found in a money-box: 1 denarius, 1 plated denarius, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Nerva - Philip I (Marcia Otacilia Severa) (AD 246-247).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.nos. M 29)

summary: 13 antoniniani: Gallienus - Tacitus (AD 276).
32 silver and provincial bronze coins: 5 antoniniani, 12 denarii, 15 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 26.1-38 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIX

summary: 81 coins of different denominations (sestertius, dupondius, as, and 1 denarius): Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

From 57 coins found on the excavated area, according to B. Prokisch 24 coins may have been part of a hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-259). A gold bracelet was found with these coins.

140 antoniniani were found on the bottom of a ceramic vessel by the excavation team of the University of Milan. Based on preliminary information drawn from the web, coins in this hoard date to the reign of Gallienus (AD 260-268).
57 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-254).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest; Museum Dunaújváros, Hungary

summary: 88 silver coins: 7 denarii, 81 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: 45.7-319.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (88 coins)

summary: 30 coins: 2 sestertii, 28 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
81 provincial bronze coins discovered in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17 096-17 176

summary: The hoard comprised both coins and other objects, including numerous items of personal adornment in precious metals as well as tableware and other vessels. One of the vessels contained approximately 395 denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Saloninus (and Valerian II?) while in the hoard as a whole, there were approximately 1080 bronze coins, nearly all sestertii, but with the exception of 12 dupondii and asses. The bronze coins range in date from Domitian (1 example) through to Trajan Decius. Testenoire-Lafayette noted that issues of Gordian III were particularly prominent in the hoard, that Severus Alexander was also well-represented and that issues of Gallienus and his family made up a large proportion of the radiates in the hoard. The hoard was found when the landowner, M. Charles demolished well-built foundations in his field which were hindering cultivation. Silver: c.395 coins;
disposition: Societé de la Diana, Montbrison, France

summary: c. 200 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 'Probably a whole hoard, offered for sale in Belgium.'
96 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Two ceramic vessels containing over 8,500 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 70 antoniniani (radiates) imitations of Tetricus I and II.
Eight radiates declared Treasure Trove in 1980, otherwise unpublished. Not part of the Sprotbrough 1980 hoard.
138 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian (AD 253-260).
A small barbarous radiate hoard in the British Museum with the provenance "Beccles, Lowestoft, 1872". No further information.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 63 antoniniani (radiates ) are known: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 3 denarii and 610 radiates from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 1756.6 and 16896.9 g.
14 silver coins, 13 known: 12 antoniniani (radiates) 1 denarius: Septimius Severus - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 4.2-33.3 g.

Before 1939, an archaeologist bought a hoard comprising 2,065 antoniniani (radiates) from a clerk in Évron. The hoard appears to have come from the north of the département, perhaps Aron or Évron, or, according to Cordonnier is another hoard from Jublains: Trajan Decius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
It comprised 3,000 antoniniani from Gallienus, Claudius II, Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Found with a copper vessel.
67 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 95.2-182.9 g.
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins, 5 of which have been identified.

In 1909, a jeweller showed Breuillac some coins from a hoard recently found in Béceleuf. He had bought approximately 3kg of coins which constituted half the hoard. Breuillac assessed approximately 2,400 coins and published a list of 135 cleaned pieces from Philip I to Tetricus I. The hoard was acquired by a jeweller and showed to Breuillac. The circumstances of discovery and the exact findspot are unknown. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 649.0-2999.0g.
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 5.3-26.2 g.

1610 antoniniani and fragments of a ceramic vessel with lid: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). The coins were minted in Siscia, Sirmium, Serdica and other mints. The majority of the coins belong to Gallienus and Claudius II. Due to poor condition of reservation 157 coins could not be identified; silver weight: 244.1-1686.4 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2731-4172, 4319-4414; 1,538 coins

summary: Hoard of circa 4,000 coins. 400 coins entered the collection of Gh. Georgescu-Corabia, including issues of Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip I.
1,103 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 296) found in a disintegrated cloth bag in an underground room during excavations of a house.
46 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of the Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274)and unidentified onject (button?).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 3 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian I, Philip I 2.
(5-6 kg) 2,000 coins. Identified 341 silver coins: 1 denarius, 340 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 259); silver weight: 2,500.2 - 4,759.1 g+.
disposition: Archeological Museum Zagreb (?980 coins); P. Broz collection Zagreb (83 coins), Croatia; dispersed - 1981

summary: The hoard comprised 160 Roman bronze and billon coins from Severus Alexander to Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The coins were found in the area of Fleischstraße 68-76 during excavation works for the construction of a store. They lay in a ceramic container (an amphora, according to some sources). Large parts of the hoard came in private possession and its full extent is unknown. FMRD gives three lists, totalling 3595 coins (all antoniniani, ranging from to ): 1) Part 1 (3351 coins; FMRD 3062,2) 2) Part 2 (Private coll.; 25 coins; FMRD 3062,3) 3) Part 3 (218 coins seen by K. Cibis, only a list of emperors is available; FMRD 3062,4) 4) Part 4 (Private coll., 1 coins; FMRD 3062,5)
28 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight: 35.0g.
651 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from M. Antony to Philip I, found in a Roman cellar south-west of the Roman fort.
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 51.2-99.8 g.
disposition: Regional History Meseum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1410-1414

summary: There is an account of Borlase receiving four radiates from the Rector of Lanreath that were found at the unidentified place of "Carlean" in 1785. The findspot was described as "near the northern extremity of [the earthwork known as] the Giant's-hedge, not far from Ethy", at Lerryn creek, on the Eastern banks of the River Fawy". Penhallurick suggests that Carlean is a misreading of Collon.
2,165 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268); silver weight: 203.5-1011.5g.
disposition: Museo d'Antichità di Torino, Italy (1,355 coins); 810 coins were bought by a junk dealer.

summary: The hoard comprised 43 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus. It was found in the same area as Oštra Luka II.
3,598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3,032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised one vessel containing 8,760 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelianus. Silver weight: 1664.9-6394.3g.
698 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
3 denarii and 31 antoniniani (radiates), but this is not certain. Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 antoniniani of Trebonianus Gallus are kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 11759-11764

summary: Unknown number of coins. 4 coins in the museum of Lovech: Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Severus Alexander, Philip II.
273 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
The hoard comprised more than 1,500 Roman coins. The Museé de Boulogne bought 100 coins ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus.
29 bronze coins: 27 setertii, 1 dupondius, 1 dupondius/as: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard was found scattered on the ground surface amongst the remains of a building and comprised 100 Roman bronze coins from Trajan to Severus Alexander. The coins were mostly worn sestertii.
64 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I/Gallienus A (253-268); silver weight: 80.0 g.

The hoard comprised an unknown quantity of coins. D. Guillony gave a portion of the hoard to the Musée de la Ville. It consisted of 31 very small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, which were for the most part unidentifiable with the exception of some coins of Tetricus. They are likely to be imitations. The hoard was found 'by chance'.
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii and dupondii from the first century AD to Gordian III, found in a large pithos. They might have been be part of a larger hoard.

44 Antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 44. Together with coin was found a male bronze statuette of 75 cm height. Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120193: 1-27; A 8173). 17 coins were lost during the period of the WWII

summary: 43 coins (1 Iron Age silver unit, 42 denarii and antoniniani ranging up to Gordian III) discovered in 1922 in a cave in the cliff above the East Wood, Ashover. A silver ring was found at the same place, in a niche between two large stones.
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised 39 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus. They were found under a layer of burnt material and many of the coins were blackened, melted or twisted. 34 coins were minted in Rome, 3 in Viminacium and 1 in Cologne with the latest coin being a Cologne issue from AD 256 to 258. Although TAF notes the mint distribution, they are not assigned to coins of particular emperors.

The hoard comprised a ceramic pot containing 60 silver and billon coins. Joullietton noted the presence of coins of Otacilia Severa ('some'), Gallienus, Saloninus and Postumus ('a large number') of which many possessed the reverse type HERC DEVSONIENSI (E. 316) The hoard was found by a farmer cutting down a cherry tree in his garden.

A hoard of four provincial coins (3 pseudo-autonomous coins of Thessalonica, with head of Tyche / ethnic - this series extends from Commodus to Philip?. The coin illustrated fig. 8-9 belongs to the latest issue; 1 Pella), found in the demolition layer of the courtyard (room ΣΤ), of a large urban Roman building.
Circa 585 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 176.4-730.3g.
Around 500 denarii found in two ceramic vessels. 230 coins provided the issuer: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205).
2 antoniniani (radiates) of unknown issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 256.
A hoard of 866 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Elagabalus, and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia, found during blasting at a quarry near Obererbach in 1944.
Unknown originally number of coins. 138 silver coins: 45 denarii, 93 antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: 181.2-323.9 g.; Septimius Severus -Philip I (AD 246-248).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (file 1951) (130 coins)

summary: In 1886 approx. 2000 coins from the time of the Tetrarchy were found in two earthenware bowls in the Emmersweiler district near Forbach, during the building of a paper mill. The coins were dispersed, but 1229 of them were published by Hettner in 1887, noting that all had the same reverse type (GENIO POPVLI ROMANI). Some coins of this hoard are now in the museums in Saarbrücken and Speyer (108 coins), but it uncertain whether these were included in Hettner's publication. This is the reason FMRD gives two lists (1100a and 1100b, here EMMERSWEILER A and EMMERSWEILER B), with list A giving the coins in the museums of Saarbrücken and Speyer, and list B the ones published by Hettner. EMMERSWEILER B also included the uncertain coins, to reach the total amount of 2000 specimens originally reported.
45 bronze coins: 44 sestertii, 1 dupondius: found together in an edifice hypotetically identified as of collegium augustales: Domitian 0- Maximinus I THrax (AD 236-238).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Municipal de Cartagena, Spain

summary: A hoard of 12 provincial coins of Gordian III and Tranquillina (Thessalonica and Edessa), found during the excavations of a farmhouse in ancient Lete (preceding the construction of the Egnatia motorway) and linked to the Gothic invasions of the middle of the 3rd c. AD.
61 silver coins found in a Roman villa: 22 denarii, 39 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 100.8-168.5 g.
Initially 857 coins, only 168 silver coins are known, and jewelry found with a : Vespasian - Aurelian (Severina) (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Civico, Lodi, Italy (nowadays, 168 coins, 1 brooch and 1 silver ring); Biblioteca Laudense, Lodi, Italy

summary: 676 Roman imperial bronzes found in the ground: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
(c. 18 kg, 4,062) 1,590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 5078.8-10559.8 g.
253 bronze coins: 252 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
Group record for a hoard of six silver coins.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 102 coins entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: 1 denarius, 101 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
A hoard of more than 2,000 coins of which only 47 were seen: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
27 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
88 silver coins: 1 denarius, 87 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Quintillus (AD 270).

18 silver coins: 4 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramic vessel: Trajan - Claudius II (AD 268-270). Together were found jewelry: 2 silver bracelets, 1 gold pendant, 3 gold rings, 1 gold earring and fragments of silver earrings.
disposition: Museo di Antichità di Torino, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised 3,604 small module radiate copies, known as 'minimi' [antoniniani (radiates)]. The hoard was found in an amphora covered by a tile while digging foundations for a building
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Natiobnale de France (in 1937)

summary: The hoard comprised 5 Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Septimius Severus, 1 Julia Domna, 1 Elagabalus, 1 pseudo-autonomous), Edessa (1 Gordian III), found in a grave.
The hoard comprised 41 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian and 16 barbarous copies; silver weight of 12.1-50.3g.

Small hoard of 15 ant. of Gallienus to Tetricus II, from 'Dover General Deposits', reported on by Peter Curnow & Richard Reece, all show evidence of wear, majority clipped.Reece, R. 2012. The Roman coins. In B. Philp The Discovery and Excavation of the Roman Shore-fort at Dover, Kent. Kent Archaeological Monographs 11. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 108.

A hoard of 16 antoniniani (Julia Domna - Gallienus), found in the shop II of the Stoa of Attalos, on the agora of Athens. The tpq for the hoard is given by the archaeological context, which corresponds to the the sack of Athens by the Heruls.
3,124 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258).
24 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1676-1699 (24 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 'more than 8,100 antoniniani (radiates), weighing approximately 30 kilos: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (172 coins; Inv. II nos. 606 and 680), France

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. 174 were studied: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 211-217)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 587 (72 coins)

summary: In 1897 a hoard of silver coins was discovered a little south of the Ladenburg/Keplerstraße junction. Only half of the coins are known, because the others were sold to America. The list given here includes a Greek coin, and 129 denarii and antoninini (late Republic to Postumus).

Around 5,000 antoniniani (radiates), 13.5 kg. The majority of coins belonged to Tetricus I and Tetricus II. Other issuers: Gallienus, Salonina, Victorinus, Postumus, Marius, Cludius II, Quintillus, Quintillus (Divus Cludius II), Aurelian.
The hoard comprised 283 tetradrachms dated between the reigns of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
191 silver coins: 132 denarii, 57 antoniniani (radiates), 2 imitations of antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised approx. 2,500 sestertii, ranging from the 1st to the 3rd century AD, finishing under Gallienus, and found in a burial in Akriai, near Gytheion.

The hoard, handed to the Serres archaeological service by a local resident, comprised 15 Roman Provincial coins (14 Koinon of Macedonia and 1 Thessalonica). It has been suggested that it is part of the Evelpidis hoard.

Over 90 coins: antoniniani, provincial bronze medallions, provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (Ad 238-244). Provincial coins were minted in: Pautalia, Serdica, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Deultum, Anchialus.
It comprised 23 coins found in "un grand mortier de pierre" (mortarium). Only 3 were identified: Augustus, Marcus Aurelius, Aurelian.
The hoard comprised 50 to 60 'copper or bronze coins' found with a ceramic vessel. The better preserved pieces included sestertii of Valerian I and Salonina.
134 silver coins: 6 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260); silver weight: 166.1-340.8 g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 'containing 9kg coins, mostly 3rd century small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, Gallienus, Postumus etc., although according to Triger there were some earlier coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, and Justine (sic). This information was repeated by numismatic reviews and by Blanchet. In 1911, Ledru wrote about the coins acquired by Julien and Louis Chappée and gave a list of emperors. A lot of 1,219 coins were bought by the Musée du Mans in 1890. The hoard was found during quarrying. Silver weight: c.812.3-7797.7g.

A hoard of 432 Roman silver coins (denarii and some antoniniani), ranging from Commodus to Trajan Decius, found in the summer of 1895 during draining works at Brickendonbury, south of Hertford. The coins lay partly in a small recess cut in the virgin clay, and partly in the soil above.
The hoard was found in 1880. It comprised 150 radiates, from Gordian III to Postumus. Only 123 are now recorded.
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), only 7 were recovered, period of AD 260-275; silver weight: c. 28.0-124.0 g.

The hoard comprised 16 barbarous radiates, all of Tetricus I and Tericus II, and 3 fragments of a copper-alloy statue. They have been interpreted as the contents of a purse, although no traces of one were found.
The hoard comprised a whiteware ceramic jug contained approximately 2,000 coins of Postumus.
356 silver coins: 294 denarii, 62 antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: 490.5-1026.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania (348 coins), County Museum Tg. Jiu, Romania (8 coins)

summary: Unknown original number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia, Gallienus, Salonina. Uncertain whether this is part of the 1840 hoard also found in Echternach.
79 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210). "Only 18 coins were found at first, the remainder being recovered when an excavation of the site was carried out the following month."

A small hoard of 45 radiates in a pot dating "to within a few years of AD 280" (Pastscape 343603) found during archaeological excavations of a Roman settlement in the Weedon Road area by Northamptonshire's Archaeological Unit in the 1970s.
A large number of denarii and antoniniani was found in a ceramic vessel. 520 denarii are kept in the museum of Ruse: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 242-243).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1705

summary: A hoard of ca. 150 Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Septimius Severus), found in Winnefeld while planting trees. 133 coins were acquired by the museum in Hannover, 117 of which can still be traced. Several coins are badly preserved and identifications are tentative.
The hoard comprised an orange paste vessel containing 3 denarii and 214 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Victorinus.
8,077 antoniniani (radiates) found with a cooking pot: Philip I to Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 1532.5-14662.1g.

A hoard was found in Chassenon at some time in the nineteenth century AD and comprised 10 coins from Maximinus I Thrax to Aemilian. Some of the coins were kept by the family and can be identified by M. Dhénin. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 12.6-22.9 g.

49 coins: 2 denarii, 7 antoniniani, 40 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); 28 provincial bronze coins of Marcianopolis and Nicopolis ad Istrum: Septimius Severus - Gordian III; silver weight: 12.1-19.7 g.
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.
The hoard comprised 658 silver coins (denarii, a few antoniniani and one drachm from Caesarea in Cappadocia) from Republican issues of Mark Antony to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Kantonsarchäologie Zürich, Fundmünzenbearbeitungsstelle, Münzkabinett der Stadt Winterthur

summary: A hoard of 551 coins, found in a drainage ditch on farmland half a mile from Llanarmon Dyffryn Geiriog, Denbighshire. Of these, 507 coins (502 denarii and 5 antoninianii, ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander) are now in the British Museum. Three further coins were reported in 1929, but the remaining ones are lost.
The hoard comprised 225 sestertii from Trajan to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).
167 silver coins: 39 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLI

summary: The hoard comprised 391 bronze coins from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. The denominational composition of the hoard was not further described.

The hoard comprised two coarseware ceramic vessels containing approximately 5,000 radiates from Gallienus, Claudius II and Aurelian, as well as issues of the Gallic Empire. 16 coins from the hoard recently reappeared and comprised issues of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Postumus and Victorinus.
265 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228).
